posts.title: I Can’t Pay My Self-Assessment Tax by 31 January. What Do I Do?
posts.excerpt: Struggling to pay your self-assessment tax bill by the 31 January deadline? Don’t panic—you’re not alone, and there are options to help you through. At Black and White Accounting, we’re here to guide you through this, one step at a time. Let’s dive into what you can do if you can’t pay on time and […]
posts.content:
Struggling to pay your self-assessment tax bill by the 31 January deadline? Don’t panic—you’re not alone, and there are options to help you through. At Black and White Accounting, we’re here to guide you through this, one step at a time. Let’s dive into what you can do if you can’t pay on time and how to manage HMRC’s deadlines and expectations with confidence.

1. Take Action Quickly—Don’t Delay!

Ignoring your tax bill is a sure way to turn a small problem into a big one. If you know you’re going to have trouble paying on time, contact HMRC as soon as possible. They understand that life happens, and there’s a system in place to help people facing financial challenges. The earlier you reach out, the more options you have!

2. Consider Setting Up a ‘Time to Pay’ Arrangement

HMRC offers a ‘Time to Pay’ (TTP) arrangement, allowing you to spread the cost of your tax bill in manageable monthly installments. This can be a real lifeline if you’re temporarily cash-strapped. Here’s how it works:

  • You can set up a TTP arrangement online if you owe less than £30,000, your tax return is up to date, and it’s less than 60 days after the payment deadline.
  • For larger amounts, or if you need longer to pay, you’ll need to speak with an HMRC adviser to discuss options. They’ll ask for details about your income, expenses, and assets, so be prepared.

3. Know the Consequences of Missing the Deadline

Missing the 31 January deadline means you’ll face penalties and interest charges from HMRC. Here’s what to expect:

  • Penalties: An automatic £100 late-filing penalty if your return is late, even if you don’t owe any tax. After three months, further penalties kick in, so don’t delay!
  • Interest: HMRC charges interest on late payments, currently at a rate of 6.5%, which can add up quickly.

4. Review Your Tax Return for Accuracy

Take a moment to double-check your tax return. Simple errors, like missed expenses or incorrect income figures, can inflate your tax bill. An accurate return could reduce the amount due, making it easier to manage payments. Our team at Black and White Accounting can review your return to ensure you’re only paying what you owe.

5. Use All Available Reliefs and Allowances

You’d be surprised how many people overlook tax reliefs and allowances! From marriage allowance transfers to claiming expenses if you work from home, every little bit counts. Our tax specialists can identify allowances you might have missed, potentially reducing your tax bill.

6. Explore Short-Term Financing Options

If a TTP arrangement isn’t enough, consider exploring short-term financing options. This could include a low-interest loan, credit card, or even borrowing from family or friends if the terms are manageable. Be mindful of interest rates, and ensure you have a plan to repay to avoid compounding debt.

7. Plan for Next Year—Take Control of Your Cash Flow

If this isn’t the first time you’ve found yourself scrambling to meet the tax deadline, it’s time to re-evaluate your cash flow strategy. Setting aside money monthly or quarterly can help you avoid a cash crunch in January. Our advisors at Black and White Accounting can help you set up a proactive tax plan tailored to your unique circumstances.

8. Stay Positive—There’s a Way Forward!

Finally, remember that not being able to pay by 31 January doesn’t spell disaster. With the right approach and timely action, you can navigate this without sinking deeper into stress or debt. At Black and White Accounting, we specialize in helping individuals like you manage their tax responsibilities with confidence and peace of mind.

Need Help? Let’s Chat!

If you’re worried about your upcoming self-assessment tax bill, contact Black and White Accounting today. We’ll review your options, explore tax-saving opportunities, and help you work out a solution tailored to your financial situation.

Don’t let tax stress weigh you down—take control, get support, and make a plan for a smoother financial future!

posts.title: Common Accounting Mistakes: Mixing Personal and Business Finances
posts.excerpt: If you’re an ambitious business owner, your days are packed with decisions, deals, and deadlines. With so much on your plate, keeping personal and business finances separate might seem like an unnecessary hassle. But trust us—mixing the two is a financial disaster waiting to happen. At Black & White Accounting, we’ve worked with fast-growing businesses […]
posts.content:
If you’re an ambitious business owner, your days are packed with decisions, deals, and deadlines. With so much on your plate, keeping personal and business finances separate might seem like an unnecessary hassle. But trust us—mixing the two is a financial disaster waiting to happen.

At Black & White Accounting, we’ve worked with fast-growing businesses like yours, and we’ve seen firsthand how this seemingly small mistake can lead to cash flow chaos, tax troubles, and financial blind spots. But don’t worry—we’re here to help you fix it before it derails your success!

Why Mixing Business and Personal Finances is a Bad Idea

🚨 Tax Nightmares – Claiming business expenses? HMRC or tax authorities won’t be impressed if your personal transactions are tangled in the mix. It could mean lost deductions—or even an audit.

💸 Cash Flow Confusion – Without clear separation, you won’t know what’s truly yours to spend and what belongs to the business. That’s a recipe for overspending or underinvesting.

🔍 Accounting Headaches – Reconciling your accounts turns into a detective mission, wasting time that could be spent growing your business.

🚀 Stalled Business Growth – Want funding or investment? Banks and investors expect clean financials—not a messy mix of business dinners and grocery bills.

Are You Guilty of This? 5 Warning Signs

❌ You use your personal bank account for business transactions.
❌ You pay for business expenses with your personal credit card (or vice versa).
❌ You transfer money back and forth between personal and business accounts with no clear tracking.
❌ Your accountant (or bookkeeper) regularly asks, “Is this business or personal?”
❌ Tax time turns into a stressful mess of sorting through old statements and receipts.

How to Fix It – The Black & White Accounting Blueprint

📌 1. Open a Dedicated Business Bank Account
This is non-negotiable! Set up a separate business account and credit card to keep things clean and professional.

📌 2. Pay Yourself a Salary
Treat yourself like an employee—transfer a set salary from your business account to your personal account rather than dipping into business funds randomly.

📌 3. Use Cloud Accounting Software
Platforms like Xero, QuickBooks, or Sage help track income and expenses, making it easy to see exactly where your money is going.

📌 4. Set Up Clear Expense Policies
If you need to make business purchases, ensure they’re logged properly. Keep digital receipts using apps like Dext or Hubdoc to track expenses efficiently.

📌 5. Work with an Expert Accountant
Separating business and personal finances might sound simple, but as your business grows, things get complicated—fast. At Black & White Accounting, we help ambitious business owners like you stay compliant, maximise tax savings, and maintain financial clarity.

Final Thoughts: Keep It Clean, Keep It Professional

Mixing personal and business finances is like pouring milk into your coffee—you can’t unmix it! The longer you wait to fix this, the harder it gets.

posts.title: The Hidden Costs of Running a Business: What You Need to Know
posts.excerpt: When you start a business, you often think about the obvious expenses: rent, salaries, inventory, and marketing. However, many entrepreneurs overlook the hidden costs that can significantly impact their bottom line. Understanding these hidden expenses is crucial for effective budgeting and long-term success. At Black & White Accounting we are here to unlock these secrets […]
posts.content:
When you start a business, you often think about the obvious expenses: rent, salaries, inventory, and marketing. However, many entrepreneurs overlook the hidden costs that can significantly impact their bottom line. Understanding these hidden expenses is crucial for effective budgeting and long-term success.

At Black & White Accounting we are here to unlock these secrets and many others besides to help you not only survive but thrive, no matter what the environment. In this blog, lets explore these hidden costs, what they are and how to manage them effectively.

What Are Hidden Costs?

Hidden costs are expenses that are not immediately apparent when launching or running a business. They can creep up on you and affect your cash flow and profitability if left unchecked. Here are some of the most common hidden costs that every business owner should be aware of:

1. Unforeseen Operational Costs

Operational costs can go beyond basic expenses. Think about maintenance for equipment, software subscriptions, and utilities. Unexpected repairs or upgrades can quickly drain your resources. Regularly reviewing your operational budget can help you identify and prepare for these potential expenses.

2. Employee Turnover and Recruitment

High employee turnover can be costly. Recruitment fees, training expenses, and lost productivity during the transition can add up quickly. Investing in employee engagement and retention strategies can mitigate these costs, ultimately saving you money in the long run.

3. Taxes and Compliance Fees

Taxes can be more complex than anticipated, especially with VAT, corporation tax, and PAYE for employees. Failing to keep track of tax obligations can result in penalties and interest. Hiring a knowledgeable accountant, like us, can help you navigate these complexities and ensure compliance, avoiding costly mistakes.

4. Insurance Premiums

While most business owners factor in basic insurance, they may overlook additional coverage options such as professional indemnity, public, employers liability, personal accident, business interruption, cyber liability, or specific industry-related insurance. Assessing your risks and ensuring you have adequate coverage is essential to protect your business from unexpected liabilities.

5. Cost of Customer Acquisition

Acquiring new customers can be more expensive than you might think. Marketing campaigns, promotional offers, and the time spent converting leads into sales can all add up. Understanding your customer acquisition cost (CAC) and continually refining your marketing strategies can improve profitability.

6. Opportunity Costs

Every business decision comes with opportunity costs—the potential benefits you miss out on when choosing one option over another. For example, investing in one project may mean forgoing another profitable opportunity. Analysing potential returns on different ventures can help you make informed choices that maximise your resources.

Managing Hidden Costs Effectively

Now that you’re aware of some of these hidden costs, here are some strategies to manage them effectively:

1. Conduct Regular Financial Reviews

Regularly review your financial statements and budgets. This practice can help you identify trends, unexpected expenses, and areas where you can cut costs. A professional accountant, like us, can assist in providing insights that may not be immediately apparent.

2. Budget for Contingencies

Set aside a portion of your budget for unexpected expenses. A contingency fund can help you navigate surprises without disrupting your operations or financial stability. Most of our clients aim to build up a fund of six-months of expenses in a separate bank account so they are ready for a rainy day.

3. Invest in Employee Development

By providing training and growth opportunities, you can enhance employee satisfaction and reduce turnover rates. Happy employees are often more productive and committed to your business.

4. Utilise Technology

Automation and software can streamline operations and reduce human error. Investing in the right technology can save time and money, improving efficiency in the long run.

5. Seek Professional Advice

Consider hiring an accountant or financial advisor, like us, to help you understand and manage your finances better. Their expertise can help you uncover hidden costs and develop strategies to improve your financial health.

Conclusion

Understanding the hidden costs of running a business is essential for maintaining profitability and ensuring long-term success. By being aware of these potential expenses and implementing effective management strategies, you can protect your business from financial pitfalls and set yourself up for sustainable growth.

Don’t let hidden costs catch you off guard. Take control of your finances today by conducting regular reviews, budgeting for contingencies, and seeking professional advice like talking to us at Black & White Accounting. With the right strategies in place, you can navigate the complexities of running a business with confidence and clarity. If you’re ready to dive deeper into your financial management, consider reaching out to an experienced accountant who can guide you through the process. Your business deserves nothing less!

posts.title: UK Company Law: A New Era of Transparency and Accountability
posts.excerpt: The landscape of UK company law is undergoing significant transformation, heralding an era of greater transparency and accountability for businesses. These changes, primarily driven by the Economic Crime and Corporate Transparency Act, are set to modernise company regulations, bolster anti-money laundering (AML) efforts, and enhance trust in the corporate system. posts.content:
The landscape of UK company law is undergoing significant transformation, heralding an era of greater transparency and accountability for businesses. These changes, primarily driven by the Economic Crime and Corporate Transparency Act, are set to modernise company regulations, bolster anti-money laundering (AML) efforts, and enhance trust in the corporate system. For fast-growing businesses and startups, understanding these changes isn’t just prudent—it’s essential for staying ahead in a competitive market.

What Is Anti-Money Laundering, and Why Does It Matter?

Anti-money laundering refers to a set of laws, regulations, and procedures designed to prevent criminals from disguising illicitly obtained funds as legitimate income. AML measures are vital for combating financial crimes such as fraud, terrorism financing, and corruption. They protect businesses from being unknowingly implicated in illegal activities and maintain the integrity of financial systems.

For businesses, compliance with AML regulations isn’t optional. Penalties for non-compliance can include hefty fines, reputational damage, and, in severe cases, criminal prosecution. This makes it crucial for companies to understand their obligations under the evolving legal framework.

Key Changes to UK Company Law

Here are the most notable updates to UK company law:

1. Introduction of Identity Verification

Directors, Persons with Significant Control (PSCs), and those filing documents with Companies House must verify their identity. This measure aims to prevent the use of fraudulent or fictitious identities in corporate structures.

2. Enhanced Powers for Companies House

Companies House will gain greater authority to query, reject, and share information. This marks a shift from being a passive registrar to an active gatekeeper of corporate data.

3. Abolition of Corporate Directors

Most corporate directors will be prohibited, with limited exceptions, to reduce anonymity and ensure accountability.

4. Tighter Rules on Registered Office Addresses

Companies must demonstrate a connection to their registered address, making it harder to use fake or improper addresses.

5. Greater Transparency in Filing Requirements

All company records will be stored digitally, streamlining processes and ensuring easy access for scrutiny.

6. Updates to Financial Reporting

Small companies will face simplified filing obligations, but certain exemptions may be removed to ensure consistent financial transparency.

Why Are These Changes Coming?

The UK government is introducing these reforms in response to increasing concerns about economic crime and the misuse of corporate entities. The aim is to:

  • Enhance the UK’s reputation as a trustworthy place to do business.
  • Protect legitimate businesses from exploitation.
  • Strengthen the ability of authorities to detect and prevent financial crimes.

Other Key Changes to Watch For

In addition to the above reforms, Companies House is expected to implement the following over the next few years:

  • Real-Time Filing: A push for near-instantaneous updates to company information to improve data accuracy and reliability.
  • Mandatory Digital Accounts Filing: All companies may soon be required to file accounts digitally using specific software.
  • Increased Collaboration: Companies House will work more closely with HMRC and other bodies to share data and combat fraud.

What These Changes Mean for Your Business

For startups and fast-growing businesses, these updates represent both challenges and opportunities. While the new regulations may require more robust compliance measures, they also promise a more level playing field, with fewer opportunities for bad actors to exploit the system.

Here’s how your business can prepare:

  • Stay Informed: Keep up-to-date with regulatory changes and their implementation timelines.
  • Enhance Compliance Procedures: Review and strengthen your internal compliance systems, especially around AML checks and record-keeping.
  • Leverage Professional Expertise: Partnering with a forward-thinking accountancy firm can ensure you’re not only compliant but also well-positioned to thrive in the new regulatory environment.

Why Choose Us?

At Black & White Accounting, we specialise in helping businesses navigate the complexities of UK company law. From AML compliance to digital accounts filing, our team is equipped to provide tailored advice that aligns with your growth ambitions. Let us help you turn these regulatory changes into strategic advantages.

posts.content:
In today’s fast-paced business environment, KPIs, or Key Performance Indicators, are essential tools for tracking progress and guiding growth. But what exactly are KPIs, and why do they matter so much?

At Black and White Accounting, we know the importance of setting clear metrics and tracking results to drive success. Here’s everything you need to know about KPIs and how they can empower your business to reach new heights!

What are KPIs?

Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) are quantifiable metrics used to evaluate the performance of an organisation, department, or individual in achieving key objectives. Think of KPIs as your business’s compass — they help measure whether you’re on the right path toward your strategic goals​ and ensure your team are pulling in the same direction as you.

Types of KPIs

  1. Financial KPIs: Measure monetary metrics like revenue growth, profit margins, and cash flow;
  2. Customer KPIs: Track customer satisfaction, retention rates, and acquisition costs to ensure you’re meeting customer needs;
  3. Operational KPIs: Monitor efficiency and productivity, such as production time, inventory turnover, or order fulfilment​; and
  4. Employee KPIs: Gauge employee performance and engagement metrics, which can influence overall productivity and morale.

Why Are KPIs Important?

KPIs provide a data-driven foundation for decision-making, allowing businesses to focus resources on areas that generate the most value. By tracking KPIs, companies can:

  • Align Team Efforts: KPIs help unify the team by focusing efforts on common goals.
  • Identify Success and Challenges: KPIs highlight both successes and areas needing improvement, allowing for quicker, more effective adjustments.
  • Enhance Accountability: With defined metrics, employees understand what’s expected, making it easier to evaluate and improve performance​.

How to Choose the Right KPIs

Selecting KPIs involves aligning metrics with your strategic objectives. Here’s how to choose KPIs that matter:

  1. Focus on Relevance: KPIs should directly relate to your specific business goals. For example, a sales-oriented KPI might track monthly new client acquisition.
  2. Be Measurable: Good KPIs are quantitative. For instance, rather than tracking “customer satisfaction,” a measurable KPI might track the “percentage of returning customers.”
  3. Set Achievable Targets: KPIs should be realistic and attainable within your timeframe. Set targets that challenge, but don’t overwhelm your team.
  4. Choose Actionable Metrics: Effective KPIs should provide insight that leads to action. If your KPI doesn’t prompt improvement or change, it may need refinement.​

Examples of Effective KPIs

  1. Financial Growth: Revenue growth rate, profit margins, and cost of goods sold (COGS).
  2. Customer Engagement: Net Promoter Score (NPS) for customer satisfaction or churn rate.
  3. Employee Efficiency: Average task completion time, or number of projects completed per quarter.
  4. Operational Excellence: Inventory turnover or lead times on product delivery​.

Top Tips for Implementing KPIs

  1. Regular Review: Track KPIs regularly and adjust as business needs evolve.
  2. Communicate Clearly: Ensure every team member understands what KPIs are being tracked and why they matter.
  3. Keep It Simple: Focus on a few critical KPIs rather than tracking too many metrics, which can dilute focus.
  4. Use Technology: Many software tools can automate KPI tracking, making it easier to generate real-time insights​.

Final Thoughts

KPIs are more than just numbers; they’re strategic tools that can guide your business toward its goals. By carefully selecting and tracking the right KPIs, you’ll gain actionable insights and drive consistent growth, or whatever is your business objective.

At Black and White Accounting, we specialise in helping businesses not only set but also understand, monitor and optimise their KPIs. If you’re ready to take your KPI strategy to the next level, contact us today! Our expert team is here to help you achieve measurable success through effective KPI management.

posts.content:
If you’re a fast-growing business owner, you’ve got big goals, big dreams, and a million things to do. But in the whirlwind of scaling up, one crucial financial task often gets overlooked—bank and credit card reconciliations.

At Black & White Accounting, we’ve seen how businesses unknowingly hemorrhage cash because they don’t reconcile their bank and credit card accounts regularly. Missing transactions, unnoticed fees, duplicate charges—it all adds up. And if you’re not keeping a close eye on your bank statements, you could be making decisions based on faulty numbers.

The good news? Fixing this mistake is easy, and it can save your business from financial disaster.

Why Ignoring Reconciliations is a Dangerous Gamble

🚨 Hidden Cash Flow Problems – Without regular reconciliations, you might think you have more money than you actually do. That’s a quick way to accidentally overspend.

⚠️ Fraud and Unauthorised Transactions Go Unnoticed – Small errors and fraudulent charges can slip through the cracks if you’re not reviewing your accounts. Banks won’t always catch them for you!

🔍 Duplicate or Missing Transactions Create Inaccurate Books – If an expense isn’t recorded or is entered twice, your financial reports will be misleading—hurting your decision-making.

💰 Tax Headaches and Compliance Issues – Incorrect or incomplete records can lead to costly tax mistakes and potential fines.

🏦 Bank Loans and Investments Become Harder to Secure – Investors and lenders expect clean, accurate financial statements. If your accounts don’t match up, you could lose out on funding.

The 5 Warning Signs of Poor Reconciliation

❌ Your bank balance never seems to match your accounting software.
❌ You find duplicate or missing transactions when reviewing your books.
❌ You discover unauthorised charges or fees months after they happened.
❌ You’re constantly scrambling at tax time to figure out where money went.
❌ Your financial reports don’t align with what’s actually in your account.

How to Fix It – The Black & White Accounting Strategy

✅ 1. Reconcile Weekly (Not Just at Tax Time!)
Make bank and credit card reconciliation a weekly habit. The longer you wait, the harder it becomes to fix discrepancies.

✅ 2. Use Cloud Accounting Software
Platforms like Xero, QuickBooks, or Sage automate reconciliations by linking directly to your bank and credit card accounts—saving you time and reducing errors.

✅ 3. Match Every Transaction Properly
Don’t just assume a transaction is correct. Check line-by-line to ensure it matches receipts, invoices, and payments.

✅ 4. Investigate Any Discrepancies Immediately
If something doesn’t add up, don’t ignore it. Investigate missing or duplicate transactions ASAP before they cause bigger issues.

✅ 5. Get an Expert Accountant to Oversee It
Growing businesses need financial accuracy. At Black & White Accounting, we help ambitious entrepreneurs like you keep your books clean, compliant, and ready for growth.

Final Thoughts: Reconciliations = Financial Confidence

Think of reconciliations like your financial reality check—without them, you’re flying blind. Don’t let avoidable errors drain your business.

posts.content:
Big changes. Bigger impact. But don’t panic—Black & White Accounting has your back.

Over the next few years, Companies House is undergoing the biggest shake-up in decades—and every business owner in the UK needs to pay attention.

Whether you run a startup, small business, or multi-entity group, new rules are coming that could affect how you report, verify, and manage your company’s information.

At Black & White Accounting, we’re keeping a close eye on the evolving picture—so you don’t have to. Here’s everything we know so far about the changes rolling out to 2027, what it means for you, and how we’ll help you stay fully compliant.

📌 Note: Some of these proposals could change with the current political landscape. This blog is accurate at the time of writing, and we’ll keep you updated on any changes as soon as we know more!

📜 A Quick History of Companies House

Companies House has been around since 1844, set up to bring transparency and accountability to UK business ownership. For years, it’s been more registrar than regulator, but that’s about to change.

The Economic Crime and Corporate Transparency Act (passed in 2023) gives Companies House new powers to crack down on fraud, fake companies, and opaque ownership structures.

In short: Companies House is moving from a “filing cabinet” to a corporate watchdog—and these new rules are designed to make UK companies more transparent, trustworthy, and trackable.

🚨 What Changes Are Coming?

Here’s a rundown of the key updates expected between now and 2027.

🆕 1. Identity Verification for Directors and PSCs

Every director and Person with Significant Control (PSC) will need to verify their identity—likely via a third-party (like us) or a new government portal.

🔐 This aims to stop fraudulent filings and fake appointments.

📑 2. Changes to Accounts Filing Requirements (the government is currently considering a U-turn on some of these – we will update you as soon as we hear any news)

Get ready for shorter, simpler, more digitally structured accounts—but with more information required, especially for small and micro-entities.

Key updates include:

  • Abolishing “abridged” and “filleted” accounts options
  • All companies filing a profit & loss account (yes—even micro!)
  • Mandated digital tagging (iXBRL) for all accounts submissions
  • Potential public access to more financial information

🧾 3. ASCP (Accounts Submission & Checking Platform) Launch

A new online submission platform is coming that:

  • Performs real-time checks on your accounts
  • Flags non-compliance instantly
  • Reduces rejections and improves data integrity

We expect this to become mandatory by 2026–2027 for all submissions.

🧍 4. More Transparency on Shareholders and Company Ownership

Companies will be required to provide:

  • Full shareholder information (not just at incorporation)
  • More detailed PSC data, with stricter update obligations
  • Possibly disclose shareholder nationality and residency (awaiting final decision)

📤 5. Enhanced Powers for Companies House

Companies House will be able to:

  • Query, reject, or remove filings
  • Share data with other government bodies (e.g., HMRC)
  • Impose penalties for false or misleading submissions

💬 Why Are These Changes Happening?

These reforms are part of a broader crackdown on money laundering, fraud, and economic crime in the UK. They’re designed to:

  • Clean up the companies register
  • Increase trust and credibility in UK business
  • Protect the UK’s global financial reputation

In other words, it’s transparency first, excuses later.

📋 Step-by-Step Guide to Get Ready

Here’s what you need to do:

✅ 1. Verify Who’s Who

Start identifying your directors, PSCs, and shareholders now. We’ll need to prepare them for identity verification.

✅ 2. Review Your Filing Practices

If you currently file abridged accounts or use a DIY method, speak to us. We’ll make sure your process is future-proof.

✅ 3. Update Your Records

Check your:

  • Registered office address
  • SIC codes
  • Shareholder register
  • PSC statements

✅ 4. Plan for Digital Compliance

We’ll help ensure your software and processes are ready for iXBRL tagging and the new ASCP.

✅ 5. Stay Informed

We’re keeping up with the latest updates, so you don’t have to. You’ll hear from us the moment something changes.

❗ Don’t Panic—We’ve Got You Covered

Yes, these are big changes.
Yes, there’s still a bit of confusion about the details.
But no—you don’t need to worry, because Black & White Accounting is here to help you every step of the way.

We’ll:

  • Explain what’s changing, when, and why
  • Handle identity verification and compliance checks
  • Update your accounting process to meet new requirements
  • Monitor updates from Companies House and the government
  • Keep your filings accurate, aligned and stress-free

🧾 In Black & White: Our Verdict

This isn’t just admin—it’s an evolution of how UK businesses operate and are held accountable.

Companies House is going digital, going detailed, and going detective. But with the right support, you’ll not only stay compliant—you’ll look sharper, stronger, and more trustworthy to everyone from clients to investors.

posts.title: Can My Employees Invoice Me for Their Overtime Instead of Going Through Payroll?
posts.excerpt: Short answer: NO. Longer answer: Let’s talk HMRC, compliance—and what you can do instead. It’s the end of a big month. Your employees have gone above and beyond. Overtime hours are racking up—and so is your payroll bill. Then someone asks: “Hey, can I just invoice you separately for the extra hours instead?” Tempting, right? […]
posts.content:
Short answer: NO. Longer answer: Let’s talk HMRC, compliance—and what you can do instead.

It’s the end of a big month. Your employees have gone above and beyond. Overtime hours are racking up—and so is your payroll bill.

Then someone asks:

“Hey, can I just invoice you separately for the extra hours instead?”

Tempting, right? Less tax. No National Insurance. No payroll faff.

❌ But here’s the deal: If they’re an employee, you cannot pay them outside of payroll.
HMRC is red-hot on this—and the penalties can be brutal.

Let’s unpack why this is a very bad idea, and what you should be doing instead to manage overtime costs legally and effectively.

⚖️ Why HMRC Says “Absolutely Not”

If someone is on your payroll, they’re an employee. All payments for work they do—even extra hours—must go through PAYE, with the appropriate deductions for:

  • Income Tax
  • National Insurance (employee and employer)
  • Pension contributions (if applicable)
  • Holiday accrual
  • Statutory protections

Trying to treat overtime as a separate invoice? That’s called disguised remuneration, and HMRC takes it seriously.

They will reclassify the payment and demand:

  • Backdated tax and NIC
  • Interest
  • Penalties (up to 100% of the unpaid tax)

Oh, and if the employee’s invoice came from a limited company? Welcome to IR35 territory. Even more risk.

🧾 Why You Can’t Be “Half In, Half Out”

You can’t have it both ways—someone is either an employee (and all pay goes through PAYE), or they’re a genuine contractor (with their own clients, autonomy, and business setup).

Here’s the problem:

If your team member looks, sounds, and works like an employee—HMRC will treat them like one, no matter what the invoice says.

🧠 So, What Can You Do to Manage Overtime Costs?

Here are some legal, strategic alternatives:

1. Agree Overtime Rates in Advance

Build it into employment contracts. You can offer enhanced rates—or not—but it must go through payroll.

2. Offer Time Off in Lieu (TOIL)

Instead of cash, allow employees to take extra paid time off later. It’s cost-neutral in the short term.

Pros: Retains morale without extra cost
Cons: Needs good tracking and management

3. Performance Bonuses

Consider setting targets and paying a structured bonus for extra work, not hours. Still via PAYE—but more motivating.

4. Hire Genuine Freelancers for Short-Term Work

Need flexible support? Use external contractors—but make sure they’re genuinely independent (own tools, multiple clients, no control).

⚠️ If you use the same person regularly, HMRC may still view them as an employee.

🔍 Other Things to Consider

  • Do you have clear overtime policies in place?
  • Are overtime hours being properly approved and tracked?
  • Is your current setup IR35-proof if using freelancers?
  • Could an EMI share scheme help reward key team members instead?

💡 At Black & White Accounting, we help clients navigate this every day—legally, strategically, and smartly.

🧾 In Black & White: Our Verdict

You CANNOT let employees invoice you for overtime.
It might feel easier, but the risks are real, the penalties are harsh, and it can seriously damage your business’s reputation.

Instead, build a solid overtime strategy that’s:

  • Compliant
  • Transparent
  • Motivating
  • Sustainable

And let us help you design it.

Let’s talk. From contracts to tax strategy, we’ve got your back—Black & White style.

posts.title: The Most Bizarre Taxes and the Lessons Learned
posts.excerpt: “In this world, nothing is certain except death and taxes.” – Benjamin Franklin In a time where the UK public purse seems tighter than ever and whispers of new taxes grow louder, we thought we’d lighten the mood a little. Here at Black & White Accounting Limited, we know that taxes can be taxing—but they […]
posts.content:
“In this world, nothing is certain except death and taxes.” – Benjamin Franklin

In a time where the UK public purse seems tighter than ever and whispers of new taxes grow louder, we thought we’d lighten the mood a little. Here at Black & White Accounting Limited, we know that taxes can be taxing—but they can also be downright bizarre.

So, before HMRC gets too creative, let’s take a whirlwind tour of some of the strangest taxes ever dreamt up by governments around the world—and what lessons we can learn before the UK decides to start taxing oxygen!

🧠 Historical Tax Curiosities: What Were They Thinking?

1. The Window Tax (England, 1696–1851)

To raise funds without directly taxing income, a levy was introduced based on the number of windows a property had. The more windows, the higher the tax. Sounds simple—until people started bricking up their windows to avoid it!

Lesson learned: Taxing lifestyle proxies can backfire—people will always find loopholes. Also, natural light should never be a luxury!

2. The Beard Tax (Russia, 1698)

Peter the Great, in a bid to modernise Russia and align it with clean-shaven Western Europe, introduced a tax on beards. Want to keep your glorious facial hair? Pay a fee and get a beard token.

Lesson learned: Social engineering through tax policy might make a statement, but it rarely wins popular support—especially from proud beard-bearers!

3. The Hat Tax (UK, 1784)

Hats were once a clear status symbol. So, of course, they were taxed. Milliners (hatmakers) were required to buy licences, and hat purchasers were charged based on the hat’s value.

Lesson learned: Targeting fashion and identity for revenue may be short-lived—fashion evolves, and so will ways to avoid the taxman.

4. The Cow Flatulence Tax (New Zealand, 2003 Proposal)

In a surprising eco-driven move, New Zealand proposed a levy on livestock emissions to combat climate change. Farmers weren’t amused.

Lesson learned: While green taxes are critical, if they hit too close to home—especially in an agricultural economy—they’ll face serious backlash.

5. The Candy Tax (USA, various states)

In some U.S. states, candy made with flour (like KitKats) is classified differently from flourless sweets (like gummy bears) and taxed at different rates. Sweet madness!

Lesson learned: Over-complicated definitions in tax codes create inconsistencies and confusion. Keep it simple (and sweet).

💡 Could These Be the UK’s Next Big (or Bonkers) Tax Ideas?

As the Treasury eyes new revenue streams, here are some “creative” options—some serious, some silly—but all worth chewing over.

1. Social Media Usage Tax

Pros: Targets time-wasting and data-hungry platforms. Revenue from the scroll-happy masses.
Cons: Hard to enforce. Would raise privacy and digital rights concerns.

2. Luxury Pet Tax

Pros: High-end pet accessories and “pawdicures” could be fair game.
Cons: Could hit ordinary pet owners with unnecessary costs. Cue public outrage (and protests led by pugs in hats).

3. Single-Use Plastics Tax 2.0

Pros: Builds on existing environmental initiatives. Politically palatable.
Cons: Potential inflationary knock-on effects and increased costs for small businesses.

4. Home Office Perk Tax

Pros: Tax deduction rollback on home office setups could plug revenue gaps.
Cons: Could feel like a punishment for flexible workers and contradict remote work incentives.

5. Digital Footprint Tax

Pros: Big Tech finally pays its “fair share” based on user interactions.
Cons: Could stifle innovation or push companies offshore.

🎯 Final Thoughts: From Folly to Fiscal Planning

History shows us that tax policy, while essential, needs to be more than just clever—it must be clear, fair, and realistic. While it’s tempting to look for quick wins or gimmicky grabs, the long-term costs in compliance, reputation, and fairness often outweigh the gains.

At Black & White Accounting, we believe in intelligent taxation—transparent, simple systems that support both government and growth. As taxes continue to evolve, our mission is to help you stay a step ahead, with clarity and confidence.

So next time you’re grumbling over your self-assessment, just be glad you’re not being taxed for your top hat, your window count… or your beard.

📣 Got a question about how changing tax landscapes might affect you or your business? Let’s talk. At Black & White Accounting, we turn tax confusion into clarity—without the beard tokens.

posts.title: Is an EMI Scheme Right for My Limited Company?
posts.excerpt: The ultimate staff incentive that could supercharge your growth. If you’re running a fast-growing company with a small team of high-performers, chances are you’ve asked yourself: “How do I keep my best people without breaking the bank?” Here at Black & White Accounting, we believe one of the smartest, most tax-efficient ways to do this […]
posts.content:
The ultimate staff incentive that could supercharge your growth.

If you’re running a fast-growing company with a small team of high-performers, chances are you’ve asked yourself:

“How do I keep my best people without breaking the bank?”

Here at Black & White Accounting, we believe one of the smartest, most tax-efficient ways to do this is the EMI scheme—but it’s not for everyone.

Let’s break down what EMI is, how it works, what it takes to set one up, and whether it’s the right move for your business.

🎯 What Is an EMI Scheme?

EMI stands for Enterprise Management Incentive—a government-approved employee share option scheme designed specifically for smaller, growing UK companies.

It lets you offer key employees the option to buy shares in your company in the future—usually at today’s price. If the business grows, they benefit from the increase in value. If it doesn’t, they’ve risked nothing.

Why it’s awesome: EMI options come with incredible tax advantages—for both you and your team.

🚀 Why Use an EMI Scheme?

Because talent is expensive—and people love feeling like they’ve got skin in the game.

An EMI scheme allows you to:

  • 🧲 Attract and retain high-calibre staff
  • 🔐 Lock in loyalty with vesting schedules
  • 📈 Reward based on future performance and growth
  • 💸 Avoid huge upfront salary costs
  • 🔥 Give a genuine sense of ownership and purpose

It’s like a pay rise—without the payroll pressure.

🧠 How Do EMI Schemes Work?

It’s simple (with the right support!):

  1. You agree a valuation for the company (with HMRC sign-off).
  2. You offer selected employees the right to buy shares in the future at today’s value.
  3. They don’t pay anything now—and only exercise if the company’s worth more later.
  4. When they sell the shares, they’ll pay just 10% Capital Gains Tax (thanks to Business Asset Disposal Relief), instead of up to 47% income tax + NICs.

💡 It’s the best of both worlds—equity without upfront tax.

🧾 What’s Involved in Setting One Up?

While the benefits are big, setting up an EMI scheme involves a few key steps and documents.

✅ The Process:

  1. Check eligibility (your company and employees must qualify—more below).
  2. Design the scheme (who gets what, when, and how).
  3. Agree your company’s share valuation with HMRC.
  4. Draft and issue option agreements.
  5. Notify HMRC within 92 days of grant.
  6. Manage the scheme with regular reviews and updates.

📄 Key Legal Documents:

  • EMI option agreement
  • Board and shareholder resolutions
  • Valuation submission to HMRC
  • Company Articles (may need tweaking)
  • Cap table and vesting schedules

Black & White Accounting can project manage the entire process—alongside your solicitor—to keep everything compliant and stress-free.

✅ Pros of EMI Schemes

  • Big tax savings for employees and employers
  • No upfront cost to the company or employee
  • Drives loyalty and retention
  • Highly flexible (performance, vesting, exit-only, etc.)
  • Increases exit value by incentivising performance

⚠️ Cons of EMI Schemes

  • Only UK-based employees are eligible
  • Directors & consultants can’t participate (though there are workarounds)
  • Legal and valuation costs to set up
  • Must notify HMRC correctly and on time
  • Dilution of shares if exercised

That’s why getting good advice (like from us) is essential.

🧱 Who Qualifies for an EMI Scheme?

To qualify, your company must:

  • Be independent and trading (not investment-based)
  • Have fewer than 250 full-time employees
  • Have gross assets under £30 million
  • Operate in a qualifying sector (excludes banking, farming, legal, etc.)

Employees must:

  • Work at least 25 hours a week (or 75% of total working time)
  • Not own more than 30% of the company

🔁 Alternatives to EMI

Not every company or team member will qualify. Here are some other ways to reward:

🟦 Growth Shares

Offer shares that only gain value if the company grows—great for future-focused incentives.

🟧 Phantom Shares

Mimic the benefits of shares (like cash bonuses on a sale), without giving away equity.

🟨 Unapproved Options

More flexible but less tax-efficient—good for non-UK team members or consultants.

🟩 Bonus + Retention Packages

Sometimes a simple cash-based scheme, tied to performance or exit, is best.

🧮 Is It Worth It?

In most cases, absolutely. If your team is tight-knit, loyal, and driving your growth—EMI can transform your retention and motivation.

Just remember: a good scheme is clear, simple, fair, and aligned with your goals.

🧾 In Black & White: Our Verdict

If you’re serious about scaling, want to hang on to key talent, and love saving tax (who doesn’t?)—then an EMI scheme is likely a game-changer.

But don’t DIY it. The best schemes are well-designed, well-documented, and well-communicated.

At Black & White Accounting, we’ll guide you through the entire EMI process—valuation, documents, HMRC filings, shareholder structures, and everything in between.

Let’s talk about how to reward your team and grow your business the smart way.

posts.title: What Are My Rights and Responsibilities as a Shareholder of a Limited Company?

posts.content:
You’ve got shares. Here’s what that really means.

You’ve got a stake in a limited company—maybe you built it from the ground up, maybe you bought in. Either way, congratulations! You’re officially a shareholder.

But now what?

At Black & White Accounting, we’re often asked:

“What can I do as a shareholder?”
“What should I be doing?”
“And what does my percentage actually give me?”

So here’s the no-fluff breakdown of your rights, responsibilities, and power level—depending on your shareholding.

👥 What Is a Shareholder?

A shareholder (or member) is someone who owns at least one share in a limited company. They’re the legal owners of the business and, depending on the number and type of shares they hold, they get a say in decisions, a slice of profits, and—ultimately—a share of the company’s value.

💡 You can be a shareholder, a director, or both—just don’t confuse the two. Directors run the business. Shareholders own it.

🎯 What Are My Rights as a Shareholder?

These depend on:

  • The number of shares you hold
  • The class of shares (e.g. ordinary, preference, non-voting)
  • The company’s articles of association
  • Any shareholders’ agreement in place

But typically, your rights include:

✅ 1. Voting Rights

You can vote on major company decisions—like electing or removing directors, approving dividends, or selling the business.

✅ 2. Dividend Entitlement

You’re entitled to a portion of the company’s profits if dividends are declared.

✅ 3. Right to Inspect Records

You can request to see company accounts and minutes of shareholder meetings.

✅ 4. Right to Transfer Shares

Subject to restrictions, you can usually sell or gift your shares.

✅ 5. Right to a Share of Capital

If the company is wound up, you’re entitled to your share of the remaining assets (after debts are paid).

📌 What Are My Responsibilities?

Owning shares isn’t just about rewards—you’ve got a few duties too:

  • Paying for your shares (if not already paid in full)
  • Sticking to any shareholder agreements
  • Acting fairly if you’re in control (especially with minority shareholders)
  • Staying informed about the company’s performance

🚫 Unlike directors, shareholders aren’t responsible for running the business or managing day-to-day operations—but they do influence big-picture decisions.

📊 Shareholding Power Levels: What Does Your % Really Mean?

Let’s talk influence. Here’s what various ownership thresholds allow you to do:

🟢 Over 75% (Super-Majority)

You’re the boss—you can pass special resolutions, which include:

  • Changing the company name
  • Amending the articles of association
  • Authorising a company sale
  • Reorganising share capital

✅ Ultimate control
🚫 But must still follow legal and fiduciary duties

🔵 Over 50% (Simple Majority)

You control ordinary resolutions, like:

  • Appointing or removing directors
  • Approving standard business decisions

✅ You can generally outvote others
🚫 You can’t change the constitution alone

🟠 More Than 25%

You can block special resolutions.

✅ A powerful minority shareholding
🚫 Can’t initiate major changes, but you can stop them

🟡 Under 25%

Limited power, but you still have rights:

  • Receive information and dividends
  • Attend meetings
  • Be treated fairly under company law

✅ You still own part of the business
🚫 Less control—unless you team up with other shareholders

⚠️ What Else Should I Know?

📄 Get a Shareholders’ Agreement

This private document outlines:

  • How decisions are made
  • How shares can be sold or transferred
  • How disputes are handled

It’s essential for avoiding headaches down the line—especially in multi-owner companies.

👥 Understand Share Classes

Not all shares are created equal. Some may have:

  • No voting rights
  • Priority dividend rights
  • Enhanced voting power

Before you assume your percentage gives you power, check the share class rules.

💬 Minority Shareholder? Know Your Protections

The law protects minority shareholders from being treated unfairly. If majority holders abuse their power, you can apply to court for ‘unfair prejudice’ relief.

🧾 In Black & White: Our Verdict

Being a shareholder isn’t just about holding equity—it’s about understanding what that equity gives you.

Whether you own 5% or 95%, your rights and responsibilities matter. And when handled well, good shareholder dynamics = a healthy, successful company.

At Black & White Accounting, we work with founders, directors, and investors to:

  • Structure equity smartly
  • Draft shareholders’ agreements
  • Build tax-efficient dividend strategies
  • Plan for exits, sales, and growth the right way

📞 Not sure what your shareholder power actually means?
Let’s talk. We’ll cut through the confusion and help you protect your position, your profits, and your future.

posts.content:
Your people are your power—here’s how to unleash it.

You’ve got the vision. The ambition. The grit. But here’s the truth: you won’t hit the next level alone.

To truly scale, you need your best people to be switched on, fired up, and pulling in the same direction. The question is: how do you get them to care about your business like it’s their own?

At Black & White Accounting, we work with fast-growing companies every day—and the difference between good and great usually comes down to how they motivate their key team members.

Here’s your no-nonsense guide to keeping your A-players engaged, loyal, and pushing hard for success—whether you’re about to scale, raise funds, or exit.

💡 First Things First: What Really Motivates People?

While money talks, meaning, recognition and opportunity often shout louder. The best motivation strategies blend financial and non-financial incentives.

Let’s dig into the tools you can use—with the pros and cons of each.

💸 Financial Motivation Strategies

1. Bonuses Linked to Performance

Think KPIs, milestones, or business-wide profit-sharing.

Pros:

  • Easy to understand
  • Encourages focus on results
  • Can be short-term or project-based

Cons:

  • Might promote short-term thinking
  • Can be expected annually (even when profits dip)

2. Salary Uplifts & Retention Bonuses

Pay increases tied to performance or loyalty milestones.

Pros:

  • Shows clear appreciation
  • Attracts and retains talent

Cons:

  • Increases fixed costs
  • Doesn’t always boost passion or engagement

3. Share Ownership / EMI Schemes

Turn your team into shareholders or future shareholders with Enterprise Management Incentives.

Pros:

  • Aligns long-term incentives
  • Great for retention
  • Highly tax-efficient

Cons:

  • Requires legal structure and HMRC approval
  • Not all employees will “get” equity right away

💡 Need help setting up EMI or Growth Shares? That’s our speciality.

🌱 Non-Financial Motivation Strategies

4. Clear Progression and Personal Development

If people see a future with you, they’re more likely to give their all today.

Pros:

  • Builds trust and loyalty
  • Retains ambitious team members

Cons:

  • Needs structure and clarity
  • Can cause friction if promises aren’t delivered

5. Involvement in Strategy & Decision-Making

Bring your key players into the room where it happens.

Pros:

  • Builds ownership and responsibility
  • Encourages innovation

Cons:

  • Takes time and transparency
  • Not everyone wants (or is ready for) that level of input

6. Recognition and Praise

Shoutouts in meetings, handwritten notes, team awards—don’t underestimate their power.

Pros:

  • Simple and effective
  • Reinforces positive behaviour

Cons:

  • Needs consistency to feel authentic
  • Doesn’t replace deeper structural incentives

7. Flexible Work and Autonomy

Freedom breeds creativity. Trust your top team to run with it.

Pros:

  • Improves wellbeing and productivity
  • Attracts top talent (especially post-COVID)

Cons:

  • Needs a strong culture of accountability
  • Not always suitable for all roles

🧠 What Else Should I Consider?

🔄 Blend & Balance

Motivation isn’t one-size-fits-all. Some thrive on bonuses; others want autonomy or purpose. Ask your team what motivates them. You’ll be surprised how often it’s not just about money.

🎯 Align Incentives with Business Goals

Want to scale revenue? Tie incentives to growth targets. Want to improve customer retention? Reward NPS or service benchmarks. Motivation only works when it’s aligned with what you need.

🧭 Create a Purpose-Led Culture

People don’t just want a job—they want to be part of something. The most motivated teams believe in your why as much as your what.

🧾 In Black & White: Our Verdict

If you want to build a business that grows fast and goes far, you need more than just good salaries. You need a team that thinks like owners, feels valued, and wants to win with you.

At Black & White Accounting, we don’t just do numbers—we help our clients build smart incentive structures that attract, engage, and retain top talent. From EMI schemes to bonus planning, we’ve got you covered.

💬 Ready to build a team that wants to go the extra mile?
Let’s talk about your next-level growth—and how we can help you get your people there too.

posts.content:
Purpose meets professionalism—with expert help from Black & White Accounting.

Thinking of giving back? Want to build something that makes a difference?

Whether you’re setting up a charitable foundation, launching a social impact initiative, or converting your cause into a formal structure—starting a charity can be one of the most rewarding things you ever do.

But it’s not just about heart—it’s about getting the structure, governance, and compliance right from day one.

At Black & White Accounting, we’ve helped numerous clients set up, run, and grow successful UK charities. Here’s our essential guide to what’s involved—and how we can help you do it the right way.

📜 A Brief History of Charities

Charities have existed in the UK for centuries, with roots going back to medieval times. The idea? Use wealth and resources to support the vulnerable and improve society.

The Charity Commission was established in 1853 to regulate charitable activities, and today, over 168,000 charities are registered in England and Wales alone.

But with great purpose comes great responsibility—and a lot of admin!

💡 What Is a Charity?

A charity is an organisation set up for a specific charitable purpose—such as relieving poverty, advancing education, promoting health, or protecting the environment. To qualify as a charity, your organisation must:

  • Be set up for exclusively charitable purposes
  • Provide public benefit
  • Be subject to Charity Commission regulation (if registered)

💬 Charities must be run by trustees, follow strict rules, and meet financial and governance requirements. It’s not just a label—it’s a legal responsibility.

🛠️ How to Set Up a Charity – Step-by-Step

Here’s your starter roadmap to turning good intentions into a legal, registered charity:

1. Define Your Charitable Purpose

This must fall under one of 13 legal categories (e.g., relief of poverty, advancement of religion, education, etc.)

2. Choose a Legal Structure

Pick the most suitable structure:

  • Charitable Incorporated Organisation (CIO) – most popular for new charities
  • Charitable Company Limited by Guarantee
  • Unincorporated Association
  • Trust

(More on the pros/cons below!)

3. Recruit Your Trustees

You’ll need a minimum of three unrelated trustees. These are the people who’ll steer the charity’s mission and stay legally responsible for compliance.

4. Create a Governing Document

This outlines your charity’s:

  • Purpose
  • Trustee powers and responsibilities
  • Decision-making rules
  • Financial controls

Usually a constitution (CIOs) or memorandum and articles (companies).

5. Register with the Charity Commission

Required if your annual income will exceed £5,000 or you’re setting up as a CIO. You’ll need:

  • Governing document
  • Trustee details
  • Proof of purpose
  • Financial projections

6. Register with HMRC

For Gift Aid and tax reliefs.

⚖️ Pros and Cons of Charities vs Other Structures

🧠 Charity not quite right? Consider a CIC (Community Interest Company) for social impact with more commercial freedom.

📊 Annual Accounting & Reporting Requirements

Once your charity is live, you’ll have ongoing responsibilities:

For All Charities:

  • Maintain accurate accounting records
  • Submit an Annual Return to the Charity Commission
  • Prepare annual accounts (accrual or receipts & payments, depending on size)

Additional for Charitable Companies:

  • Submit accounts and confirmation statement to Companies House
  • File Corporation Tax returns (if relevant)

💡 If your income exceeds £25,000, you’ll need an independent examiner—and if over £1m, a full audit may be required.

💷 VAT and Corporation Tax: What to Watch

Charities can enjoy generous tax breaks—but they’re not tax-exempt by default.

Corporation Tax

  • No tax on primary purpose trading or donations
  • But non-charitable trading (e.g., commercial sales) may be taxable

VAT

  • VAT registration is still required if your taxable income exceeds the threshold
  • Some charity-specific VAT exemptions apply (e.g., certain advertising, fundraising events)
  • But VAT can get complex, especially for mixed-use income or property

🧾 Black & White Accounting can help you navigate this maze—and avoid surprise tax bills.

🧾 In Black & White: Our Verdict

Starting a charity isn’t just about passion—it’s about planning.

Done well, you can build an organisation that’s:

  • Purpose-led
  • Financially efficient
  • Grant-eligible
  • Tax-optimised
  • Trusted by the public

But if you get the structure or paperwork wrong, you risk delays, penalties—or worse, failing to achieve your mission.

That’s why Black & White Accounting is here.

👏 How We Can Help

Whether you’re at idea stage or already up and running, we offer:

  • Charity setup and registration support
  • Structuring advice (CIO vs trust vs company)
  • Charity-specific bookkeeping and reporting
  • Independent examinations and audits
  • Gift Aid and VAT planning
  • Ongoing compliance and trustee support
  • Strategic advice to grow your impact sustainably

📞 Thinking of launching a charity—or want to make yours stronger?
Let’s talk. We’ll help you build a purpose-led organisation that’s not just compliant, but confident, efficient and thriving.

posts.content:
From Dog Sitters to Netflix Subs (Yes, Really), These Deductions Might Shock You

Let’s be honest—Self-Assessment tax returns are no one’s idea of fun. But what if we told you… you could claim more than you think? At Black & White Accounting Limited, we help sole traders, freelancers, directors and landlords unlock clever tax reliefs they didn’t even know existed. And sometimes, those allowable expenses are downright surprising. So before you file (or panic), ask yourself: “Can I claim that?” Because the answer might just be… yes.

🧾 First – What Counts as an Allowable Expense?

HMRC’s rule is simple (ish):

If it’s “wholly and exclusively” for the purpose of your business—it’s likely claimable. That doesn’t mean 100% business use only. You can also apportion costs (e.g. your phone or energy bills). And there are specific reliefs and allowances that go beyond just receipts. Let’s dive into the fun stuff.

🎉 10 Surprising Self-Assessment Reliefs & Deductions You Might Be Missing

1. 📱 Your Mobile Phone

Use your mobile for work and personal? You can still claim a proportion-based on your usage.

Bonus: Same goes for broadband and landline.

2. 🎬 Netflix, Spotify or TV Subscriptions

If you’re a content creator, journalist, media pro, or performer-HMRC may accept entertainment subscriptions as a business expense.

✅ Just make sure it directly relates to your trade.

3. 🧑‍🎓 Training Courses

Learning a new skill to expand your business? Training may be claimable-especially if it’s directly relevant to your trade or improves current knowledge.

🚫 Not claimable if it’s completely unrelated (e.g. a yoga teacher learning coding).

4. 🐶 Security Dogs

Have a business premises that requires security-or a dog that protects your home office?
Some sole traders in rural areas or high-risk zones have successfully claimed guard dog costs or alarm monitoring fees.

✅ We’ll guide you if it’s legit.

5. 🎭 Makeup, Costumes and Uniforms

If your work involves performing, public appearance, or branding-costumes, hair, and makeup might be deductible.

📸 This includes influencers, actors, and public-facing entrepreneurs (like YouTubers).

6. 🚘 Car Wraps & Branding

Did you wrap your car with your business logo or website? That’s a marketing cost!

Just keep proof, and we’ll help claim it properly.

7. 🏠 Part of Your Rent or Mortgage Interest

Working from home? You can claim a proportion of:

  • Rent (or mortgage interest)
  • Utilities
  • Council tax
  • Cleaning
  • Internet and insurance

We help you calculate it accurately and fairly.

8. 🛠 Tools and Equipment (Even Fancy Laptops!)

Anything you use to do the work-whether that’s a high-spec laptop, toolkit, microphone, or ring light, it can usually be claimed.

✅ Even if it’s under £1,000, you may qualify for Annual Investment Allowance or a simple deduction.

9. 👦 Childcare Costs

Childcare costs can be claimed for any childcare needs during the school holidays.

Let us advise before you claim.

10. 🧳 Travel and Overnight Stays (Including Meals)

Client meetings, training events, or trade shows?
Travel, hotels, taxis, and meals on the go are claimable—but not your daily commute.

💸 Bonus: Don’t Forget the Big Ones

Still shocked? Here are some less surprising but often overlooked reliefs:

  • £1,000 Trading Allowance
  • Business mileage (45p per mile)
  • Capital allowances for home office furniture
  • Charitable donations (Gift Aid)

And if you’re married, the Marriage Allowance transfer can save up to £252 per year with a simple tick box.

🤝 Why It Pays to Have Us on Your Side

At Black & White Accounting Limited, we don’t just tick boxes. We:

✅ Know what’s allowable and what’s risky
✅ Help you claim everything you’re entitled to
✅ Maximise refunds and reduce your bill
✅ Keep you fully compliant with HMRC
✅ Do it all in plain English—not tax jargon

Don’t leave money on the table—or get penalised for guessing.

🏁 Final Word: If in Doubt, Ask (Don’t Guess)

“Can I claim that?” is our favourite question.
Because the answer is often yes—with the right advice.

So if you’re a business owner, creator, landlord, or freelancer—it’s time to get serious about claiming what’s yours.

📞 Not Sure What You Can Claim?

posts.title: CCJ: Everything You Need to Know
posts.excerpt: If the term “CCJ” sends a shiver down your spine—you’re not alone. Whether you’ve received one, worried you might, or just want to understand what it means for your finances or business, we’ve got you covered. In typical Black & White style, we’re here to cut through the confusion and give you everything you need […]
posts.content:
If the term “CCJ” sends a shiver down your spine—you’re not alone. Whether you’ve received one, worried you might, or just want to understand what it means for your finances or business, we’ve got you covered.

In typical Black & White style, we’re here to cut through the confusion and give you everything you need to know—straightforward, practical, and with your future in mind.

📜 A Brief History of the CCJ

A County Court Judgment (CCJ) is a legal tool used in England, Wales, and Northern Ireland. It’s been part of the UK’s legal system since the 19th century, and its role remains the same: to formally settle unpaid debts through the courts.

While the way judgments are recorded and enforced has evolved with digital systems and online courts, the principle remains unchanged: you owe money, a creditor has gone to court, and now you’re officially obliged to pay.

⚖️ What Exactly Is a CCJ?

A County Court Judgment is a court order that tells you to repay a debt. It means a creditor has taken legal action and won their case.

It can be issued to:

  • Individuals
  • Sole traders
  • Partnerships
  • Limited companies

Once it’s registered, it becomes part of your credit file—and it stays there for 6 years, unless you take specific steps to remove it.

🚨 How Does a CCJ Arise?

A CCJ doesn’t come out of nowhere. Here’s how it typically unfolds:

  1. You owe someone money (a creditor like a lender, utility company, or supplier).
  2. They try to collect—maybe by sending reminders, calling, or using debt collectors.
  3. They issue a formal “Letter Before Action”, giving you a final chance to pay or respond.
  4. They apply to the County Court for a judgment.
  5. The court sends you a “Claim Form”—you usually have 14 days to respond.
  6. If you don’t respond or fail to pay, a CCJ is issued against you.

🧹 How Can You Remove a CCJ?

All is not lost! You have options—especially if you act fast:

1. Pay Within 30 Days

If you pay the full amount within 30 days of judgment, the CCJ won’t appear on your credit file. It’s like it never happened.

2. Pay After 30 Days

The CCJ stays on your file but is marked as “satisfied”—better than nothing when lenders look you up.

3. Apply to Set It Aside

If you didn’t receive the court papers or think the CCJ was issued unfairly, you can apply to have it ‘set aside’. You’ll need evidence—and often legal help.

4. Wait It Out

If unpaid, a CCJ will automatically disappear six years after the judgment date, though your credit will take a beating in the meantime.

🧭 What Can You Do Once You Have a CCJ?

If you’ve got a CCJ, take action. Here’s how to regain control:

  • Pay it off as soon as you can.
  • Negotiate payment terms with the creditor or via the court.
  • Seek advice—the right support can make a big difference.
  • Monitor your credit score to understand how the CCJ is affecting your profile.
  • Prioritise other debts to avoid getting more CCJs.

At Black & White Accounting, we’ve helped many clients negotiate settlements and rebuild their credit footprint after a CCJ—there is life after one!

💣 What’s the Impact of a CCJ?

Let’s be blunt: CCJs are serious. Here’s how they affect you:

  • ❌ Credit rating hits rock bottom—getting loans, credit cards, or even a mobile contract becomes difficult.
  • 🏠 Mortgage refusals—lenders may reject your application outright.
  • 🚗 Higher insurance premiums—yes, insurers check your credit.
  • 👔 Damaged business reputation—especially for company directors or sole traders.

In short, a CCJ can feel like financial quicksand—but there are ways to climb out.

🛡️ How to Avoid a CCJ in the First Place

Prevention is better than cure. Here’s how to dodge the dreaded judgment:

  • Don’t ignore debt letters—burying your head won’t make it disappear.
  • Communicate with creditors—most are open to repayment plans.
  • Keep good records—you’ll need them if things escalate.
  • Get professional advice early—we’re here to help you spot trouble before it lands in court.

🧠 Other Handy Tips

  • A CCJ against your limited company will appear on Companies House and impact your credibility with suppliers and clients.
  • You can search for CCJs using the Registry Trust if you suspect one might have been issued.
  • Businesses and landlords often check for CCJs as part of due diligence—don’t get caught out.

✅ In Black & White: Our Verdict

At Black & White Accounting, we believe understanding your financial position is the first step toward taking back control. Whether you’ve had a CCJ, fear one’s on the way, or just want peace of mind, we’re here to offer straight-talking, expert support.

We don’t judge—we help.

💬 Need advice or a check-up on your credit status?
Let’s talk. We’ll walk you through your options, help you avoid long-term damage, and get you back on solid ground.

posts.content:
Short answer: No. Longer answer? Here’s why it’s risky—and what you should consider instead.

Let’s say it how it is: staffing costs are high. Employers’ National Insurance, pensions, holiday pay, sick pay, admin, compliance… it adds up fast.

So it’s no surprise that we hear this question from business owners all the time:

“Can’t I just switch my employees to contractors to save money?”

It’s a tempting idea—no PAYE responsibilities, fewer benefits, greater flexibility… what’s not to like?

Here’s the truth: HMRC hates this idea. And if you get it wrong, it could cost you more than you save.

Let’s break down why this isn’t the silver bullet it seems—and what smart alternatives you can explore.

❌ Why HMRC Says No: “Disguised Employment”

You can’t just relabel someone a contractor and carry on as normal. If they work like an employee, they’re an employee—no matter what the contract says.

This is known as “disguised employment”, and HMRC is actively hunting it down.

They’ll look beyond the paperwork and assess the true working relationship based on:

🚦 Key Employment Indicators:

  • Do they work set hours?
  • Do they have to do the work themselves (no substitution)?
  • Are they under your control (told what/when/how to work)?
  • Are they integrated into your team (email address, company laptop, management hierarchy)?
  • Can they make a profit/loss? Do they use their own tools or hire others?

If the answers look like “yes” to most of those—you’ve got an employee, not a contractor.

🔍 What Happens If HMRC Catches You?

HMRC will reclassify the worker as an employee—retrospectively. That means you could owe:

  • Backdated PAYE and NICs (both employer and employee portions)
  • Interest on underpaid tax
  • Penalties of up to 100% of the unpaid tax

Oh, and your “contractor” could sue for unpaid holiday, pension, or unfair dismissal rights too.

Bottom line: It’s not worth the risk.

🤝 What About IR35?

If you’re working with contractors through their limited companies, IR35 rules apply. For medium and large businesses, it’s your responsibility to determine if the contractor is genuinely self-employed.

If you get it wrong under IR35, you foot the tax bill—not them.

💡 Black & White Accounting can help you run IR35 assessments and reduce risk.

✅ What Can You Do Instead?

If you’re looking to reduce costs sustainably and safely, consider:

1. Flexible Working Contracts

Offer part-time, job share, or variable hours arrangements that still comply with employment law.

2. Freelancers for Project-Based Work

True freelancers, operating independently and outside your control, are fine. Just be sure it’s a genuinely independent engagement.

3. Zero-Based Budgeting

Start from scratch and re-evaluate every cost. Don’t just slash payroll—look at processes, subscriptions, systems.

4. Use Contractors Properly

Need someone short-term for a specific deliverable? Hire a contractor with their own clients, tools, and schedule. But keep it legit.

5. Offer EMI Share Options

Motivate key team members with ownership—not salary hikes. It’s tax-efficient and builds loyalty without extra cash outlay.

Want to know more about EMI schemes? We’ve got a blog on that too.

🧾 In Black & White: Our Verdict

Trying to disguise employees as contractors to save tax is a big, red-flag no-no. HMRC will see right through it—and punish accordingly.

But that doesn’t mean you’re stuck.

  • Navigate IR35 and employment status rules
  • Optimise workforce structure legally and ethically
  • Explore cost-saving staffing strategies that don’t break the law
  • Implement incentives like EMI schemes, performance bonuses, and lean operating models

posts.excerpt: You’re not alone—and here’s how to fix it. Your sales are flying. Your team is growing. Your customers are raving. On paper, your business is booming. posts.content:
You’re not alone—and here’s how to fix it.

Your sales are flying. Your team is growing. Your customers are raving. On paper, your business is booming.

But here comes the crunch:
👉 The month ends… and there’s barely any cash left in the bank.

Sound familiar?

At Black & White Accounting, we see this all the time—successful, growing businesses running on financial fumes. And guess what? It’s not just you.

Let’s dive into why this happens, what you can do about it, and how we help businesses like yours turn success into sustainable, cash-rich growth.

🧠 So, Where Is All the Money Going?

If your P&L says you’re winning but your bank account disagrees, chances are you’re facing one (or more) of these classic culprits:

1. Timing Mismatch (aka “The Cash Gap”)

You’re invoicing like a boss… but your customers are paying late. Meanwhile, you’re paying your staff, suppliers, rent and taxes right now.

Result: You’re profitable—but not liquid.

2. Overtrading

You’re growing faster than your cash flow can handle. More sales mean more stock, bigger wages, more overheads… but the cash hasn’t landed yet.

Result: The faster you grow, the worse your cash flow becomes (yes, really!).

3. High Debtor Days

If you’re giving customers 30, 60, or even 90 days to pay—and not chasing hard—you’re financing their business, not yours.

Result: Cash tied up in invoices you can’t spend.

4. Poor Margin Control

You’re selling more, but not making enough per sale. Maybe costs have crept up without you noticing, or pricing hasn’t kept pace.

Result: You’re busy, but not profitable enough to see cash stack up.

5. Big Tax Bills Creeping Up

VAT, Corporation Tax, PAYE—if you’re not forecasting ahead, those chunky payments can wipe out your buffer overnight.

Result: “Surprise” tax bills that were completely predictable.

💡 How Do I Get Out of the Month-End Cash Struggle?

1. Tighten Up Debtor Control

  • Introduce clear payment terms
  • Automate reminders and credit control
  • Offer early settlement discounts
  • Charge interest on overdue invoices

Pros: Faster cash in the door
Cons: May impact client relationships (but a polite nudge goes a long way)

2. Forecast Like a CFO

Get a 13-week rolling cash flow forecast that maps income, outgoings, VAT, salaries, and peaks/troughs.

Pros: Predict and plan for cash crunches
Cons: Needs updating and accuracy—don’t do it half-heartedly

3. Review Pricing and Margins

Are you actually charging enough? Small margin improvements can have huge bottom-line impact.

Pros: Improves profitability fast
Cons: May need value-based pricing strategy (we can help!)

4. Access Working Capital

Consider short-term finance like:

  • Invoice finance
  • Business overdraft
  • Growth loans

Pros: Keeps you trading while waiting on cash
Cons: Interest costs + you must stay disciplined

5. Slash Hidden Costs

Reassess subscriptions, supplier deals, inventory holding, and wastage. Cash isn’t just made—it’s protected.

Pros: Improves net cash position without selling more
Cons: Needs regular attention and a sharp eye

🧾 In Black & White: Our Verdict

Having low cash doesn’t mean your business is failing. In fact, it often means you’re growing. But without visibility, systems and strategy, it can feel like you’re chasing your tail.

Black & White Accounting helps business owners like you:

  • Diagnose the root of the cash problem
  • Build powerful cash flow models
  • Set up automated debtor tracking
  • Optimise pricing and profitability
  • Create tax-saving, cash-holding strategies

💬 Our Clients Say…

“I thought I was smashing it, until we had to delay paying a VAT bill. Black & White helped us sort our cash flow, and now I finally feel in control again.”
– Emma, E-commerce Founder

🏁 Final Thought

More sales are great. More cash is better.

If you’re feeling like your bank balance doesn’t reflect your hard work, you don’t need to guess your way through it. Let us help you turn your momentum into money in the bank.

📞 Want to finally feel confident about your cash flow?
Let’s talk. No jargon, no judgment—just clarity, strategy and results.
