posts.content:
The No-Nonsense Guide to Getting Construction Tax Right

Whether you’re laying bricks, managing sites, fitting kitchens or working on new builds—if you’re in construction, then CIS applies to YOU.

That’s right: The Construction Industry Scheme (CIS) isn’t just for big firms or major developers. It affects sole traders, subcontractors, limited companies, and even property investors dipping their toes into development.

At Black & White Accounting Limited, we work with hundreds of businesses in the construction sector—and we’ve seen the same mistakes made time and time again. So let’s break down what CIS really is, why it matters, and how to stay HMRC-compliant without losing your mind (or your money).

🧱 What Is CIS?

The Construction Industry Scheme is HMRC’s way of making sure tax is deducted before it gets spent.

If you’re a contractor, you’re legally required to:

  • Verify subcontractors with HMRC
  • Deduct tax from their payments (20% if registered, 30% if not)
  • Report and pay those deductions to HMRC monthly

If you’re a subcontractor, you’ll have tax deducted before you get paid—but don’t panic: it counts as advance tax on your year-end return, and you may be due a refund.

✅ CIS is not optional—if you’re in scope, you must comply.

👷 Who Counts as a Contractor or Subcontractor?

You’re a contractor if you:

  • Pay others to carry out construction work (even if it’s not your main business)
  • Spend more than £3 million on construction in any 12-month period
  • Are a property developer, housing association, or local authority hiring workers for building-related tasks

You’re a subcontractor if you:

  • Get paid by contractors for construction services
  • Are self-employed or a limited company (not on PAYE)
  • Work as a plumber, electrician, decorator, roofer, etc.

🛠️ You can be both! Many businesses act as subcontractors on some jobs and as contractors on others.

🔍 What Work Falls Under CIS?

CIS covers a lot more than you might think:

Included in CIS:

  • Building work
  • Demolition
  • Repairs and refurbishments
  • Installation of lighting, heating, security systems
  • Groundwork, site prep and scaffolding
  • Painting and decorating

❌ Excluded from CIS:

  • Architects and surveyors
  • Carpet fitting
  • Delivering materials
  • Some professional consultancy services
  • Manufacturing of off-site materials
  • Hiring plant (without operators)

📍 It’s the work done on-site that usually counts—and this is where contractors often get caught out.

💸 How CIS Deductions Work

Let’s say you’re a subcontractor invoicing a contractor for £1,000 of labour.

  • The contractor verifies you with HMRC.
  • You’re registered? They deduct 20%, pay HMRC £200, and pay you £800.
  • You’re not registered? The deduction is 30% instead. Ouch.
  • You still invoice for the full £1,000—it’s just split between you and HMRC.

➡️ These deductions count toward your income tax and NI bill at year-end. You might even be owed a refund.

🧾 How to Register for CIS

Contractors must:

  • Register as a contractor on the HMRC website
  • Verify each subcontractor before paying
  • Deduct the correct amount (and not on materials)
  • Submit a monthly CIS return to HMRC
  • Give each subcontractor a payment and deduction statement

Subcontractors must:

  • Register with HMRC under CIS
  • Provide UTR and verification details to contractors
  • Keep records and include deductions on their tax return
  • Claim a refund or offset the deduction against their Corporation or Income Tax

📍 Need help? We register and manage this entire process for our clients.

💡 Common Mistakes (and How to Avoid Them)

  • ❌ Not verifying subcontractors before paying
  • ❌ Deducting tax on materials (this shouldn’t happen!)
  • ❌ Missing monthly return deadlines—resulting in automatic penalties
  • ❌ Not giving subcontractors proper deduction statements
  • ❌ Thinking CIS doesn’t apply because you’re “just a small builder”

These slip-ups can lead to fines, tax investigations, or lost cash flow. We help clients avoid every single one.

💻 Software to Simplify CIS

With MTD (Making Tax Digital) requirements growing, it’s time to ditch the spreadsheets.

We help clients use smart, HMRC-friendly software like:

  • Xero
  • QuickBooks
  • Sage
  • FreeAgent

These tools can:

  • Automate CIS deductions
  • Generate reports and statements
  • Link with payroll, VAT and bookkeeping
  • Submit monthly CIS returns directly to HMRC

📍 Less admin. Less stress. More time on-site.

🤝 How Black & White Accounting Can Help

CIS is complex—but it doesn’t have to be hard.

At Black & White Accounting Limited, we help construction businesses:

  • ✅ Register for CIS (contractor & subcontractor)
  • ✅ Set up compliant software systems
  • ✅ Run monthly CIS returns & HMRC payments
  • ✅ Maximise refunds on overpaid deductions
  • ✅ Ensure zero penalties and full peace of mind

We work with builders, electricians, roofers, joiners, developers, and property investors who want their finances as solid as their projects.

🧱 Final Word

CIS isn’t just tax—it’s a cash flow issue, a compliance risk, and a major business decision.

Whether you’re just starting out or scaling fast, CIS affects your profit, your paperwork, and your peace of mind.
Let’s make it work for you—not against you.

posts.content:
Innovators, Rejoice—You Don’t Have to Choose Between Them

So, you’ve secured a grant to fund your next big idea. Amazing.
You’re building, developing, experimenting, and making it happen.

But then someone tells you:

“If you’ve had grant funding, you can’t claim R&D tax credits.”

🚫 WRONG.

At Black & White Accounting Limited, we’re here to clear the confusion and help you claim both—legally, strategically, and successfully.

Because the truth is…

✅ Yes, you CAN claim R&D tax relief even if you’ve had a grant.
But HOW you do it makes all the difference.

Let’s break it down.

🧪 First, a Quick Refresher: What Are R&D Tax Credits?

R&D (Research & Development) tax credits are a government incentive that lets UK limited companies claim back up to 27% of their eligible innovation costs—whether you’re profitable or loss-making.

You can get money back for:

  • Staff wages
  • Subcontractor costs
  • Software and cloud tools
  • Prototypes and materials
  • Utilities related to development

Even if your idea flopped—you could still be rewarded for trying.

💰 And What About Grant Funding?

Grants are non-repayable funds awarded to help your business grow. They might come from:

  • Innovate UK
  • Horizon Europe
  • Local Growth Funds
  • Private or university partnerships

They’re brilliant for innovation—but they do interact with R&D tax credits in specific ways.

🤯 So… Can I Claim Both?

Yes—but not always on the same cost, and not always under the same scheme.

Here’s the key:

There are two main R&D schemes:

  1. SME R&D Scheme – The more generous one, for most small businesses
  2. RDEC Scheme – Slightly lower rates, but compatible with grant funding

If your project is:

  • Fully funded by a notified state aid grant → those costs must go through the RDEC scheme
  • Partially funded by a grant → you split the costs
  • Funded by a non-notified or de minimis grant → you may still use the SME scheme for some costs

🔍 Real Example: How It Works in Practice

Imagine this:

You received a £50,000 Innovate UK grant. You also spent another £80,000 of your own funds on the project.

Here’s how you might claim:

  • The £50,000 grant-funded part goes through the RDEC scheme (~20% return)
  • The remaining £80,000 (if qualifying) could go through the SME scheme (up to 27% return)

That’s a total potential cash benefit of over £25,000.

🚨 But if you or your accountant get the allocation wrong, you could lose thousands.

⚠️ Common Pitfalls to Avoid

❌ Claiming the grant-funded portion under the SME scheme
❌ Not separating out eligible vs. ineligible costs
❌ Assuming one project = one scheme (you can split!)
❌ Failing to track how grant funds were actually spent
❌ Missing out completely because “someone said you can’t claim both”

📊 How We Help You Maximise BOTH

At Black & White Accounting, we:

✅ Analyse your grant agreements to understand the funding type
✅ Track your cost allocation across R&D activities
✅ Identify which costs qualify for SME, RDEC—or both
✅ Create HMRC-compliant reports with zero fluff
✅ Handle the full submission and keep you stress-free

The result? More funding, fewer errors, and faster payouts.

🔁 Grants + Tax Credits = Smart Strategy

Here’s the thing:

Grant funding and R&D tax relief aren’t enemies.
They’re powerful partners in your growth strategy—when used properly.

Whether you’re a startup raising Innovate UK cash, or a scale-up looking at Horizon Europe support, you don’t have to pick sides.

🏁 Final Word: Don’t Leave Money on the Table

You’ve worked hard to build something new.
Don’t let a technicality cost you thousands in lost tax relief.

With the right advice, you can claim both grant funding and R&D tax credits—legally, cleanly, and confidently.

Let’s make that happen.

posts.content:
The Smart Director’s Guide to Paying Yourself (Without Paying the Price)

You’ve worked hard. The business is growing. Profit’s on the table.
Now comes the big question:

“Should I take the money out—or leave it in the company?”

It’s not just a cashflow decision—it’s a tax, strategy, and growth decision. And the wrong move could mean thousands in unnecessary tax or missed opportunities.

At Black & White Accounting Limited, we help ambitious business owners get clear, confident, and tax-savvy about one of the biggest decisions directors face.

Let’s break down when it’s smarter to extract your profits, and when it pays to let them build inside your business.

🧠 First, Who Owns the Profit?

As a director-shareholder, your limited company is a separate legal entity. That means:

  • The company earns profit
  • You don’t automatically own it
  • You can only take it out through salary, dividends, or loans

So while it feels like it’s your money—it’s only yours when you extract it properly (and pay the tax).

💰 Option 1: Draw It Out (Take the Profit)

Taking money out of your company is essential—but how and when you do it matters.

🔄 Main Options:

  • Salary – taxed as PAYE income
  • Dividends – taxed at lower rates, but only from post-tax profit
  • Director’s Loans – temporary, but watch out for Section 455 tax

💸 Pros of Drawing Profit:

  • You get paid—obviously
  • Can fund your personal lifestyle, mortgage, pension
  • Spreads your income over time
  • May avoid future tax hikes (use your allowances now!)

😬 Cons:

  • You may lose access to cash you could reinvest
  • Dividends can’t exceed profits—no profit = no payout
  • Overdrawing can trigger extra Corporation Tax (on loans)

✅ Best for: Directors who need personal income now and want to optimise annual allowances (salary + dividends combo is usually most efficient).

🏦 Option 2: Leave Profit in the Company

Letting profits build up in the business has serious benefits—especially if you’re thinking big.

💡 Pros of Retaining Profit:

  • Company pays only 19–25% Corporation Tax (vs 40–45% on personal income!)
  • You can reinvest in growth—new hires, stock, tech, R&D
  • Build reserves for future tax bills, downturns, or funding projects
  • Can help with mortgage affordability (some lenders prefer retained profit)
  • Delays personal tax until you actually take the cash

⚠️ Cons:

  • Money isn’t “yours” until you extract it
  • Sitting on large cash reserves might trigger HMRC scrutiny
  • If you die without extracting it, your estate may pay extra Inheritance Tax (unless you’ve done IHT planning)

✅ Best for: Businesses planning to scale, reinvest, or retain flexibility. Also powerful for directors with multiple income sources or tax band considerations.

🧮 The Strategy: Blend Both

The smartest move isn’t either/or—it’s a well-planned combo:

Example:

  • Take a salary up to £12,570 (tax-free personal allowance)
  • Draw dividends up to your basic-rate band
  • Leave the rest in the company to reinvest or extract later at a lower tax rate

This approach:
✅ Optimises tax
✅ Keeps you personally cash-healthy
✅ Builds business resilience

🔍 At Black & White Accounting, we model this strategy specifically for your goals, tax position, and business needs.

🧠 Bonus Tip: Use Profit for Pension Contributions

Want to extract cash from your company and reduce Corporation Tax?

Your company can pay employer pension contributions directly to you. It’s:

  • 100% Corporation Tax deductible
  • Tax-free for you personally
  • Outside your estate for IHT (if done right)

📈 A long-term tax win.

💥 What NOT to Do

Here’s what gets directors in trouble:

❌ Overdrawing the DLA

Borrowing cash from the company and not repaying it = Section 455 tax (32.5%) + benefit-in-kind risk.

❌ Paying Dividends Without Profit

Illegal—and flagged instantly in an HMRC audit.

❌ Taking Too Much Too Fast

Pulling all profits without planning = higher personal tax + loss of cash buffer + zero investment capacity.

🤝 How We Help You Get It Right

At Black & White Accounting, we:

  • ✅ Calculate your optimal director’s salary/dividend split
  • ✅ Forecast Corporation Tax + personal tax outcomes
  • ✅ Model different drawdown options and timings
  • ✅ Ensure HMRC-compliant documentation
  • ✅ Help with pensions, loans, and group strategies
  • ✅ Review it all before your year-end—not after it’s too late

No guesswork. No nasty tax surprises. Just bold, black-and-white advice that supports your goals.

🚀 Final Word: Take What You Need, Build What You Want

The real question isn’t just “Should I take the profit?”
It’s “What’s the smartest way to use it—to fund my life AND grow my business?”

Let us help you make that call with confidence.

posts.excerpt: In a post-pandemic world, the question of where we work has become just as important as how we work. posts.content:
In a post-pandemic world, the question of where we work has become just as important as how we work. Whether you’re running a start-up, scaling a business, or navigating changes in your industry, choosing between working from home, hybrid working, or working from the office is more than just a logistical decision—it can make or break productivity, team cohesion, and even profitability.

So, what’s best for your business? Let’s take a look.

A Brief History: How COVID-19 Changed Work Forever

Before 2020, remote working was often seen as a luxury, reserved for tech companies or forward-thinking freelancers. The traditional office setup reigned supreme, with long commutes and desk-bound routines. But then came COVID-19—a global pandemic that triggered the world’s biggest experiment in remote work almost overnight.

According to ONS data, nearly 50% of UK employees worked from home during the first lockdown. Suddenly, kitchen tables became offices, video calls replaced boardroom meetings, and businesses discovered they could operate with surprising resilience—even without the office.

What started as a short-term solution became a long-term shift. As the dust settled, three dominant models emerged:

  • Remote-First (Work from Home)
  • Hybrid Working
  • Office-Based Working

The Pros and Cons of Each Working Model

Working from Home

Pros:

  • Cost Savings: Reduced office overheads, utility bills, and commuting costs.
  • Flexibility: Employees enjoy a better work-life balance.
  • Access to a Wider Talent Pool: Hire talent from anywhere, not just your local area.

Cons:

  • Isolation: Lack of in-person interaction can impact morale and mental health.
  • Collaboration Challenges: Creative problem-solving and spontaneous discussions are harder remotely. This is particularly a potential issues for trainees and junior members of the team.
  • Productivity Gaps: Not everyone thrives without structure or a dedicated workspace.
  • Expert Insight: A 2023 study by McKinsey found that 41% of remote workers felt more productive, but only 20% of managers agreed—highlighting the perception gap.

Hybrid Working

Pros:

  • Best of Both Worlds: Combines face-to-face collaboration with remote flexibility.
  • Increased Autonomy: Employees feel more trusted and empowered.
  • Retention and Attraction: A popular choice among Millennials and Gen Z workers.

Cons:

  • Complex Coordination: Scheduling meetings and aligning team days can be a logistical headache.
  • Unequal Experience: If not managed well, remote employees may feel excluded from key decisions.
  • Expert Insight: According to CIPD (Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development), 63% of UK employers said hybrid working boosted productivity in 2023.

Working from the Office

Pros:

  • Team Cohesion: Stronger workplace culture and quicker communication.
  • Easier Supervision: Managers find it easier to monitor performance and offer guidance. This is particularly important for trainees and more junior members of a team.
  • Access to On-Site Tools: Useful for industries reliant on physical infrastructure.

Cons:

  • Commuting Time: A major contributor to employee dissatisfaction and burnout.
  • Overheads: Rent, utilities, and office maintenance costs can add up.
  • Limited Flexibility: May hinder employee retention in a world where flexibility is a key demand.
  • Expert Insight: Gallup research indicates companies with rigid in-office policies experienced higher staff turnover than those offering flexible options.

What’s Right for Your Business?

There’s no one-size-fits-all answer. The right approach depends on factors, such as your:

  • Industry & Operations: Do you rely on physical space or customer-facing roles?
  • Team Dynamics: Are your employees self-motivated or do they thrive in groups?
  • Business Goals: Are you scaling fast or stabilising operations?
  • Technology Infrastructure: Can your systems support remote or hybrid working securely?

It may also be worth piloting different models and collecting employee feedback before committing to a long-term structure.

Other Useful Considerations

  • Cybersecurity: Remote work introduces new risks—have you got the right systems in place?
  • Tax Implications: Are your WFH allowances, business premises, and employee benefits optimised?
  • Productivity Tracking: Avoid micromanagement—focus on outputs, not hours worked.
  • Wellbeing Support: Mental health resources, ergonomic equipment, and social engagement are crucial across all models.

Why Black & White Accounting Isn’t Just Your Typical Accountant

At Black & White Accounting, we don’t just help you keep the lights on—we challenge your thinking to help you shine. We’re not box-tickers or spreadsheet-jugglers. We’re your business partner.

Whether you’re considering moving to remote-first operations or struggling to balance hybrid logistics, we bring not just accountancy but strategic insight, business planning, and tailored financial advice to the table.

We understand that the workplace has changed. So should your business strategy.

Let’s work together to figure out what’s right for you—not just on paper, but in practice.

Ready to challenge your business thinking?

Contact Black & White Accounting today and discover how we can help you achieve your goals—whether you’re working from home, the office, or somewhere in between.

posts.content:
Think You Don’t Qualify? You Might Be Leaving Thousands on the Table

If you’ve ever thought “R&D tax credits aren’t for us,” you’re not alone.

Too many small businesses are missing out on one of the UK’s most generous tax reliefs because of outdated assumptions, bad advice, or industry myths.

At Black & White Accounting Limited, we’ve claimed millions in R&D relief for companies just like yours—often after they said, “We didn’t think we qualified.”

So let’s set the record straight.

🚫 Myth #1: “R&D is only for scientists in white coats”

Busted:
You don’t need a lab, goggles or a PhD to qualify.

If you’ve:

  • Developed new products
  • Built custom software
  • Solved a technical problem
  • Improved a manufacturing or business process

Then you may be doing R&D—even if your team wears hard hats, aprons, or hoodies instead of lab coats.

✅ We’ve claimed for:

  • Breweries improving shelf-life
  • Builders developing new fireproofing methods
  • Agencies automating marketing platforms
  • Designers testing sustainable materials

If it wasn’t straightforward—you might qualify.

🚫 Myth #2: “You need to be making a profit to claim”

Busted:
Loss-making businesses can benefit too—and often do.

In fact, if you’re pre-revenue or investing heavily in development, you could receive a cash credit from HMRC.

📉 Even if you’ve never paid a penny of Corporation Tax, the government might pay you back for your innovation.

Typical SME cash credit: up to 18.6% of qualifying spend.

🚫 Myth #3: “Only big companies can claim R&D tax credits”

Busted:
Small businesses and startups are some of the biggest winners.

The SME R&D scheme is specifically designed for:

  • Companies with fewer than 500 employees
  • Under €100M turnover

Even if you’ve only got a few team members, if you’ve spent time solving complex problems—you may qualify.

And with Black & White Accounting on your side, the process won’t feel “too big” for you.

🚫 Myth #4: “You can only claim if the project was successful”

Busted:
You don’t have to win to claim. You just have to try.

In HMRC’s eyes, it’s the attempt to overcome uncertainty that counts—not the final result.

So:

  • Failed prototypes? ✅
  • Abandoned software builds? ✅
  • Iterations that didn’t work? ✅

If you learned, tried, tested, and used skilled people to do it—you’re in R&D territory.

🚫 Myth #5: “It’s too complicated and time-consuming”

Busted (especially with us):
R&D claims don’t have to be painful.

At Black & White Accounting Limited, we make it:

  • Clear
  • Fast
  • Compliant
  • Jargon-free
  • And aligned with your wider tax strategy

We’ll handle the technical report, cost analysis, and submission—so you can get on with innovating while we work on claiming.

💡 Bonus: What Can You Claim For?

  • Staff wages & NIC
  • Subcontractors & freelancers
  • Cloud software & licences
  • Materials & prototypes
  • Utilities related to the project

You can claim for two years back—so even past projects may still be cash-positive!

🏁 Final Word: Still Think R&D Isn’t for You?

If you’re building, designing, improving, testing, or solving problems…

posts.content:
You’re Probably Sitting on Thousands in Tax Relief (Without Realising It)

Bought a van for your business? A laptop? Renovated your office or upgraded machinery?

Guess what—that spending could slash your Corporation Tax bill.
Welcome to the world of capital allowances—HMRC-approved, totally legal, and massively underused.

At Black & White Accounting Limited, we call capital allowances a tax hack for smart business owners—because when you know how they work, you stop leaving cash on the table.

Let’s break it down.

🧠 What Are Capital Allowances?

Capital allowances are tax deductions for certain business purchases—typically assets that will last longer than a year.

Instead of treating them as day-to-day running costs (like rent or wages), HMRC lets you deduct the cost gradually or in full, depending on the rules.

The result?
💥 Lower taxable profits = Lower Corporation Tax

🏗️ What Can You Claim Capital Allowances On?

You might be surprised at what qualifies.

✅ Common Assets That Qualify:

  • IT equipment (laptops, monitors, servers)
  • Tools and machinery
  • Company vehicles (vans, EVs, plant)
  • Furniture and fittings
  • Air con, lighting, and electrical systems
  • Fixtures inside business premises
  • Integral features (e.g. lifts, heating)

❗Bonus: Some R&D costs also cross over into capital allowances.

🔥 The Main Types of Capital Allowances

Here’s where it gets juicy.

1. Annual Investment Allowance (AIA)

Claim 100% of qualifying costs, up to £1 million per year.

So if you buy £20k of new office kit—boom 💥—you can deduct it all in year one.

2. Full Expensing (New from 2023)

Businesses can deduct 100% of qualifying main pool assets with no cap.

Especially valuable for:

  • Manufacturers
  • Construction firms
  • Businesses investing heavily in infrastructure or kit

3. First-Year Allowances (FYA)

Applies to certain green or energy-efficient equipment (including electric cars). You can claim 100% in year one.

⚡ Example: Buy an electric company car? You may be able to claim FYA + 0% benefit-in-kind (BiK) for the director. That’s huge.

4. Writing Down Allowances (WDA)

For assets not covered by AIA or FYA, you deduct the cost over time (usually 18% or 6% per year depending on the asset class).

📉 Not ideal, but better than nothing.

💷 Real-Life Example: The £15,000 Tax Saving

A growing design agency buys:

  • New iMacs and tech: £12,000
  • Office refit and lighting: £28,000
  • Electric van: £30,000

Instead of spreading the deductions over years, they use:

  • AIA and FYA to claim £70,000 total in capital allowances this year
  • That saves them up to £17,500 in Corporation Tax (at the 25% rate)

🎯 Real money back in the business, fast.

😬 What If You Miss a Claim?

Here’s the kicker:

If you don’t claim it—you lose it.

Or worse, you underclaim and pay more tax than you legally need to.

That’s why your accountant needs to:

  • Know exactly what qualifies
  • Categorise your assets correctly
  • Time purchases strategically before your year-end
  • Include it properly in your CT600 (Corporation Tax return)

📍 Don’t leave this to guesswork or software alone.

🤖 Capital Allowances & MTD Software

Using cloud software like Xero, QuickBooks, FreeAgent, or Sage helps you:

  • Tag capital assets properly
  • Create asset registers
  • Track depreciation
  • Share info with your accountant in real time

🧠 But software is only as good as the setup—we configure it so you never miss a claim.

🤝 How Black & White Accounting Helps You Claim Smarter

We go beyond basic compliance. Our team:

  • ✅ Reviews asset purchases before year-end
  • ✅ Advises what to bring forward to maximise claims
  • ✅ Handles complex categories (like refurbishments or EV fleets)
  • ✅ Works with your software to automate future claims
  • ✅ Audits prior years for missed opportunities

We’ve recovered £5k, £10k—even £30k+ in overlooked capital allowances for growing clients. You could be next.

🚀 Final Word: Don’t Buy Assets Blind—Buy Them Smart

Capital allowances aren’t a loophole—they’re a built-in business benefit for companies that invest and grow.

Whether you’re a startup buying your first Mac or a property business renovating a commercial unit, the tax savings are real—and often bigger than you think.

posts.content:
Perks, Payroll and PAYE—What You Need to Know Before You Say “It’s On Us!”

Who doesn’t love a good perk?

Whether it’s a company car, private healthcare, or Friday Deliveroo on the boss, staff benefits can boost morale, loyalty, and your reputation as a brilliant employer.

But here’s the kicker…

Some of those perks are taxable—and some are not.
And if you don’t get it right, HMRC will absolutely want a word.

At Black & White Accounting Limited, we help business owners reward their team the right way—compliantly, tax-efficiently, and with no nasty surprises.

Let’s break down what counts as a Benefit in Kind (BIK), what goes through PAYE, and how you can offer generous perks without triggering a payroll headache.

🧾 What Is a Benefit in Kind (BIK)?

A Benefit in Kind is any non-cash benefit an employee or director receives because of their employment—and which has a personal benefit or money’s worth.

Think:

  • Company car 🚗
  • Health insurance 💊
  • Gym memberships 🏋️
  • Rent-free accommodation 🏡

These benefits are usually taxable, and either:

  • Reported via P11D at year-end
  • Or processed in real-time through payroll (PAYE)

✅ What Staff Benefits Are Not Taxable?

Here’s the good news. Some benefits are completely tax-free, provided you follow the rules:

🎁 1. Trivial Benefits

These are small, infrequent perks under £50 in value, such as:

  • A birthday bottle of wine 🍷
  • A team lunch 🎉
  • A thank-you M&S voucher 🛍️

📌 They must not be cash or a reward for work performance, and directors of close companies are limited to £300/year in trivial benefits.

💻 2. One Work Mobile Phone

You can provide one phone per employee—no tax, no NI, no problem.
It must be:

  • Provided by the employer
  • The contract in the business’s name
  • Not reimbursed personal bills

🚆 3. Work-Related Travel Expenses

You can reimburse:

  • Public transport to a client meeting
  • Overnight accommodation on business
  • Mileage (at approved HMRC rates)

✅ These are not taxable if they meet the wholly, exclusively and necessarily test.

🎓 4. Job-Related Training

Courses that improve job performance or enhance workplace skills?
Totally fine. No tax. Encourage away!

🩺 5. Eye Tests & Glasses

If your employee uses a screen, you can cover eye tests and basic glasses needed for screen use. No tax here either.

❌ What Staff Benefits Are Taxable?

These are the perks that do trigger a tax charge, either via P11D or through payroll.

🚗 Company Cars

One of the most heavily taxed benefits. Tax depends on:

  • The car’s value
  • Its CO₂ emissions
  • Fuel type

🧠 Top Tip: Electric vehicles have far lower BIK rates (2% for 2025)—worth considering for directors!

🏥 Private Health Insurance

A classic BIK. The value of the policy is taxable on the employee, and subject to Class 1A National Insurance for the business.

🏠 Accommodation

If you offer rent-free or subsidised housing—unless it’s for the job (e.g. a school caretaker)—it’s a taxable benefit.

🏋️ Gym Memberships

If you provide a gym membership (and it’s not on-site), it’s taxable—even if it’s for health and wellbeing.

🎟️ Entertainment Perks

Tickets, event invites, or lavish staff parties over £150 per head/year can become taxable on the employee. Watch the limit.

🧮 How to Report Staff Benefits

There are two ways to stay compliant:

1. P11D + P11D(b)

  • File P11D for each employee receiving taxable benefits
  • File P11D(b) to report Class 1A NIC due from the employer
  • Deadline: 6 July after the end of the tax year

2. Payroll Benefits Through PAYE

You can choose to “payroll” benefits monthly (e.g. private health cover)

  • This spreads tax payments out
  • Avoids the year-end paperwork
  • Must register with HMRC before the start of the tax year

📌 We can handle both options for you, seamlessly.

🤖 Why Use MTD-Compliant Software for Staff Benefits?

With cloud software like Xero, QuickBooks, Sage, and FreeAgent, you can:

  • Record perks and expenses in real-time
  • Run accurate payroll with benefits included
  • Submit PAYE and Class 1A NIC automatically
  • Keep all records tidy for HMRC reviews

And with Black & White Accounting managing your payroll, every benefit is tracked, taxed (if needed), and handled stress-free.

🧠 Pro Tips for Smart Employers

  • ✔️ Keep a clear benefits register—even for “small stuff”
  • ✔️ Consider payrolling benefits to avoid P11D drama
  • ✔️ Use trivial benefit rules strategically
  • ✔️ Choose tax-efficient perks like pensions and training
  • ✔️ Speak to us before offering a new benefit—we’ll help you design it tax-smart

🤝 How Black & White Accounting Can Help

We offer:

  • ✅ Full PAYE setup and reporting
  • ✅ P11D and benefits processing
  • ✅ Advice on tax-free vs taxable perks
  • ✅ MTD-compliant payroll software integration
  • ✅ Strategic planning for directors’ benefits

We help you reward your team without triggering unnecessary tax charges.

🚀 Final Word: Benefits Should Feel Like a Bonus—Not a Burden

Your staff deserve to feel valued.
You deserve to offer perks without tripping over PAYE.
And your business deserves to keep HMRC happy.

With the right planning and support, you can offer awesome perks, boost morale, reduce tax, and stay fully compliant.

posts.content:
The what, when, and how of turning employees into business partners.

Running a fast-growing company is a bit like climbing a mountain: you need a strong team with you for the long haul—not just people collecting a payslip, but those who genuinely care about reaching the summit with you.

So, how do you reward and retain those ride-or-die team members?

You guessed it: share ownership.

At Black & White Accounting, we’ve advised countless founders and directors on whether, when, and how to offer shares to their key people. So here’s everything you need to know—in plain English and with no fluff.

🤝 Why Give Shares to Employees at All?

Put simply, shares make your top performers feel like owners. It aligns their goals with yours—grow the business, share in the rewards.

Done well, offering shares can:

  • 💪 Boost motivation
  • 💸 Attract and retain top talent
  • 🧠 Encourage long-term thinking
  • 🧭 Share responsibility and vision
  • 📈 Add value to your business ahead of investment or exit

But beware—it’s not always sunshine and equity. You need to get the timing, structure, and strategy right.

🕰️ When Should You Offer Shares?

This is the golden question. Some signs it might be time:

✅ You’re scaling fast

And you need to lock in talent who’ve helped build the business.

✅ You’re preparing for investment

VCs love seeing committed, incentivised leadership teams.

✅ You’re approaching an exit

It’s a great way to reward loyalty—and boost business value.

✅ You want to keep someone who’s irreplaceable

And they’re already asking “What’s next for me here?”

But beware: don’t offer shares too early. Wait until you know:

  • They’re genuinely committed long-term
  • You’ve seen their impact on business success
  • Your company is worth sharing

⚙️ How Does It Actually Work?

There are a few ways to structure this, depending on your goals and your business:

1. Straight Shares

You issue shares directly to the employee. They become a shareholder today.

Pros: Simple and clear.
Cons: Immediate tax implications, loss of some control.

2. Growth Shares

Shares that only have value if the company grows beyond a certain point.

Pros: Protects existing value; aligns reward with new success.
Cons: Needs solid legal drafting.

3. EMI Share Option Scheme (Enterprise Management Incentive)

A hugely tax-efficient way to grant share options to employees that can be exercised later.

Pros: Brilliant tax treatment, flexible, HMRC-approved.
Cons: Only for qualifying companies (and not for consultants or non-employees).

💡 We help loads of clients set these up—it’s one of the smartest ways to reward staff without big upfront costs or tax bills.

⚖️ Pros and Cons of Offering Shares

✅ Pros:

  • Increased loyalty and performance
  • Attract top-level hires
  • Shares feel more valuable than just cash
  • Easier to compete with larger firms
  • Employees think like business owners

⚠️ Cons:

  • Dilution of your ownership
  • Potential loss of control (depending on rights)
  • Complexity in set-up and agreements
  • Can cause tension if not managed transparently

🔢 How Many Shares Should You Offer?

This is a common concern—and it depends on a few things:

  • Your company’s valuation
  • How crucial the individual is to future growth
  • How many other people you might want to reward
  • Your own long-term exit or ownership goals

A typical range:

  • 0.5%–2% for rising stars or senior hires
  • 5%–10% for founding team members or high-impact roles
  • Up to 25% total across all employees, but this varies

🎯 Tip: Don’t just give shares. Tie them to milestones, vesting periods, or continued employment.

📋 Key Considerations Before You Offer Shares

  • ✔️ Put a shareholders’ agreement in place
  • ✔️ Consider vesting schedules (they earn shares over time)
  • ✔️ Protect founder control with non-voting shares or special rights
  • ✔️ Take tax advice early—don’t get stung!
  • ✔️ Communicate clearly with the team—no surprises or legal jargon

🧾 In Black & White: Our Verdict

Giving shares to your key team members can be one of the smartest moves you ever make—if done right. It’s about rewarding loyalty, securing your talent, and building a business where everyone wins when the business wins.

But move too fast, offer too much, or get the structure wrong—and it can cost you more than just equity.

That’s why Black & White Accounting is here. We’ll help you:

  • Design the right scheme (including EMI if eligible)
  • Value your shares fairly
  • Navigate the legal and tax side
  • Communicate clearly with your team

💬 Thinking of giving away a slice of your pie?
Let’s make sure it grows first—and that you do it in a way that’s smart, strategic, and tax-efficient.

posts.content:
One Boosts Your Drive—The Other Boosts Your Pay. But Which Wins on Tax?

It’s the classic employee (or director) dilemma…

“Should I take the company car… or just take the cash and sort myself out?”

On the surface, a shiny new car sounds like a dream.
No lease payments, no repair bills, and a status symbol to boot.

But dig a little deeper, and there’s one three-letter detail that changes everything:

BIK – Benefit in Kind.

At Black & White Accounting Limited, we help clients figure out what’s really in their best interest—not just on paper, but on their payslip. And today, we’re breaking down the true cost of company cars versus cash alternatives, so you can make the smart, tax-efficient choice.

💡 What’s a Benefit in Kind (BIK), Again?

A Benefit in Kind is any perk you get through your employer that has a personal benefit—and HMRC expects tax on it.

Company cars are the most common and costly BiK out there.

Why? Because even though your employer pays for the car, HMRC treats it like extra income.

🚘 The Company Car: Perk or Pitfall?

If your company gives you a car for personal use (even just evenings and weekends), that’s a taxable benefit.

Here’s how the tax is calculated:

  1. List price of the vehicle (not the price paid)
  2. Multiplied by a BIK percentage, based on CO₂ emissions and fuel type
  3. Multiplied by your income tax rate (20%, 40%, or 45%)

💡 The greener the car, the lower the BIK charge.

🚗 Real Example: Hybrid vs Diesel

Option A: Diesel Car

  • List price: £30,000
  • CO₂ emissions: 130g/km
  • BIK rate: 30%
  • Annual taxable benefit: £9,000
  • Employee tax: £1,800 (20%) or £3,600 (40%)

Option B: Electric Car

  • List price: £30,000
  • CO₂ emissions: 0g/km
  • BIK rate (2025/26): 3%
  • Annual taxable benefit: £900
  • Employee tax: £180 (20%) or £360 (40%)

✅ See the difference? Choosing electric could save you thousands in tax.

💷 What If You Take the Cash Instead?

Some employers offer a “car allowance”—extra cash in your salary to use how you wish.

Sounds great, but here’s the catch:
That cash is fully subject to Income Tax and National Insurance.

£6,000 car allowance:

  • Taxed as salary
  • You lose 20%–45% income tax
  • And 12% employee NICs (plus employer NICs too)

🧠 Translation: You could lose £2,000+ in deductions on that “perk”.

📊 The Ultimate Showdown: Car vs Cash

✅ Best for tax savings: Electric company car
✅ Best for flexibility: Car allowance
✅ Worst for tax: Petrol/diesel company cars (unless low emissions)

🧾 Don’t Forget the Hidden Extras

When comparing, consider:

  • Fuel benefit charge if your employer pays for personal fuel
  • Maintenance & insurance (covered with company cars)
  • Mileage allowance if you use your own car for work
  • Salary sacrifice options for electric vehicles (huge tax win!)

🤝 How Black & White Accounting Can Help

Whether you’re an employer deciding what to offer, or an employee/director weighing your options—we help you:

✔️ Calculate the real after-tax impact
✔️ Choose vehicles that minimise BIK tax
✔️ Set up salary sacrifice EV schemes
✔️ Comply with P11D and Class 1A NIC obligations
✔️ Avoid overpaying or underreporting to HMRC

🏁 Final Word: Don’t Let the Flashy Option Cost You Dearly

A company car can be a great benefit—or it can quietly eat away at your take-home pay.

If you’re not sure whether to opt for the car or take the cash, don’t guess.

Let Black & White Accounting Limited run the numbers and help you drive a smarter tax decision.

posts.content:
Your Guide to Getting It Right with MTD and Staying Ahead of the Curve

The days of spreadsheets and paper files are behind us. HMRC wants your VAT records digital, secure, and connected.

But what exactly does that mean? What counts as a digital record? And how can you make compliance quick, simple, and stress-free?

At Black & White Accounting Limited, we’re not just here to tick the compliance box—we help businesses thrive by staying ahead of the curve. This guide will break down what HMRC expects, what we recommend, and how to turn digital VAT into a business advantage.

Let’s go.

🧾 A Quick Recap: What Is VAT and Why Has It Gone Digital?

VAT (Value Added Tax) is a tax applied to most goods and services sold in the UK. If you’re VAT-registered, you must charge VAT on sales, reclaim VAT on expenses, and submit VAT returns to HMRC.

Enter: Making Tax Digital (MTD).
Launched in 2019, MTD is HMRC’s initiative to modernise the tax system, reduce errors, and bring small businesses into the 21st century.

As of April 2022, all VAT-registered businesses must:

  • Keep VAT records digitally
  • Submit returns using MTD-compliant software

Failure to do so? Risk fines, lost data, or stressful audits.

🧠 What Does HMRC Expect from You?

Here’s a breakdown of what HMRC requires when it comes to digital VAT records:

✅ 1. Digital Record-Keeping

You must store key VAT information digitally. This includes:

  • Business name and VAT number
  • VAT accounting scheme used
  • VAT on sales and purchases (incl. rate, amount, and date)
  • Total daily gross takings (if using retail schemes)
  • Adjustments or corrections made

Spreadsheets can be used—but only if linked via digital bridging software. Manual copy-paste is no longer acceptable.

✅ 2. Functional Compatible Software

You must use MTD-approved software that can:

  • Digitally record VAT data
  • Preserve digital links between records
  • Submit VAT returns directly to HMRC

That means no more manual calculations or typing values into the HMRC portal.

🧾 What We Recommend (Because Good Enough Isn’t Good Enough)

At Black & White Accounting, we go beyond what’s required—we help clients set up a VAT system that saves time, improves accuracy, and supports growth.

Here’s what we recommend:

💻 1. Use Fully Integrated Cloud Software

We suggest ditching spreadsheets altogether and switching to:

  • Xero
  • QuickBooks
  • FreeAgent
  • Sage

These platforms:

  • Keep digital records in real-time
  • Auto-calculate VAT as you go
  • Categorise transactions with ease
  • Create digital audit trails
  • Link directly to your bank
  • Submit VAT returns in a couple of clicks

It’s not just about compliance—it’s about running your business smarter.

⚙️ 2. Automate Wherever Possible

Let software handle:

  • Invoice generation (with correct VAT rates)
  • Expense tracking (snap receipts on the go)
  • Bank reconciliation
  • VAT reporting deadlines & reminders

Automation = less human error, faster returns, and no more spreadsheet headaches.

🔐 3. Keep Records Secure and Backed Up

Cloud accounting tools store your data safely, but we also recommend:

  • Two-factor authentication
  • Regular data exports (just in case)
  • User access controls (so only the right people see what they need)

MTD might seem like a burden, but it’s actually a huge step up in data security and resilience.

🧾 Bonus: What You No Longer Need to Do

Thanks to digital records:

  • ❌ You don’t need to keep paper receipts (scanned copies are fine)
  • ❌ You don’t need to re-enter figures for every VAT return
  • ❌ You don’t need to worry about storing physical ledgers

But you do need to keep your digital records for at least 6 years—and keep them organised.

🤝 How Black & White Accounting Can Help

We make MTD compliance seamless.

Whether you’re:

  • A startup registering for VAT for the first time
  • A retailer managing multiple VAT rates
  • A service provider with international clients

We’ll help you:

  • ✅ Choose and set up the best MTD software
  • ✅ Digitise your VAT records properly
  • ✅ Train your team or manage your VAT for you
  • ✅ Submit accurate, stress-free returns
  • ✅ Prepare for any HMRC review with complete confidence

We’re not just about tax—we’re about peace of mind, saved hours, and scalable systems.

💬 Final Thoughts

Digital VAT compliance isn’t just a rule—it’s a smart move.
The right tools and team can make it effortless and even empowering.

If you’re still stuck in spreadsheet mode, worried about errors, or not sure if your setup ticks HMRC’s boxes—it’s time for a better way.

posts.content:
Unlock Tax Efficiency, Asset Protection & Growth Power

You’re building something great—maybe even more than one business. You’ve got profits, plans, and a few late-night thoughts like:

“Should I set up a holding company?”
“Can it actually help me pay less Corporation Tax?”
“Is it just for big corporations—or can it work for me too?”

Spoiler: If you’re a business owner or director with multiple income streams, big growth ambitions, or valuable assets to protect, a holding company could be a game-changing move.

At Black & White Accounting Limited, we help clients structure smarter, grow faster, and reduce tax bills legally. And holding companies are one of the most powerful tools in the playbook.

Let’s break it down.

📦 What Is a Holding Company?

A holding company is a limited company that doesn’t trade or provide services—it simply owns shares in one or more subsidiary companies.

It acts like a parent, holding:

  • Equity in your trading companies
  • Property or IP (intellectual property)
  • Investments
  • Cash reserves

📍 It’s a legal structure, not a tax dodge—and when set up properly, it’s HMRC-compliant and packed with perks.

💡 How Can a Holding Company Save You Corporation Tax?

Here’s where things get exciting. Done right, a holding structure can help you:

1. Avoid Corporation Tax on Dividends Between Companies

If your trading company pays a dividend to you personally, you’ll likely face Dividend Tax on top of Corporation Tax.

BUT…

If your trading company pays that dividend to your holding company, there’s no tax on it at all—it’s typically exempt under UK rules.

💥 That means profits can be passed up tax-free and reinvested elsewhere within your group.

2. Protect Cash from Trading Risk

Trading companies are exposed to risk—lawsuits, supplier disputes, cash flow issues.

A holding company can:

  • Extract surplus profits out of the trading company via dividends
  • Hold them safely outside of legal risk
  • Use them to invest in new businesses or assets

📍 Think of it as a tax-efficient safety vault.

3. Use Group Relief to Offset Profits & Losses

Got one profitable company and another making a loss?

With a group structure:

  • Losses in one subsidiary can be offset against profits in another
  • This can reduce the overall Corporation Tax bill

📊 This is called Group Relief, and it’s a powerful way to reduce tax without wasting losses.

4. Sell a Trading Subsidiary—Tax-Free

Yes, you read that right.

Under the Substantial Shareholding Exemption (SSE), if your holding company sells shares in a subsidiary (under the right conditions), it could:

  • Pay 0% Corporation Tax on the gain
  • Keep 100% of the sale proceeds inside the group
  • Reinvest them in another venture, property, or new trading business

🧠 It’s one of the most misunderstood—and underused—tax reliefs in the UK.

5. Create a More Flexible Growth Vehicle

A holding company lets you:

  • Spin off new ventures without starting from scratch
  • Separate risk between different businesses
  • Prepare for investment or sale with clean structure
  • Move assets (with planning) between subsidiaries

All while controlling everything from the top.

👀 When Does a Holding Company Make Sense?

Consider one if:

  • You run multiple businesses or income streams
  • You want to protect assets (like property, cash, or IP)
  • You’re planning to sell a company in future
  • One business is growing faster than another
  • You want to minimise dividend tax and reinvest profits
  • You want to build a long-term legacy structure

📍 It’s not just for big corporations—we’ve helped startups, landlords, and consultants benefit from group structures.

🚨 BUT… Get Professional Advice First

While the tax benefits are powerful, there are:

  • Set-up costs and admin
  • Group VAT and payroll implications
  • Rules around connected companies, SSE, and HMRC anti-avoidance
  • Company law to consider

⚠️ Set it up wrong, and you could lose the benefits—or worse, trigger a tax bill.

That’s where Black & White Accounting steps in.

🤝 How We Help

We’ve structured holding companies for clients in:

  • Construction
  • Property investment
  • eCommerce & retail
  • Professional services
  • Tech startups
  • Media & creative agencies

Our team will:

  • ✅ Design the right group structure for you
  • ✅ Handle all Companies House and HMRC registrations
  • ✅ Ensure you qualify for tax exemptions
  • ✅ Help you with dividend planning and intercompany loans
  • ✅ Manage your accounts across the group
  • ✅ Keep you fully compliant (no nasty surprises)

🚀 Final Thought: Build It Right from the Start

A holding company isn’t just about tax—it’s about strategy, security, and scale.

Done properly, it can help you:

  • Grow multiple businesses under one roof
  • Protect what you’ve built
  • Unlock huge tax advantages
  • Create something you can pass on, sell, or spin off

Let us help you build a structure that works for your vision, not just your tax return.

posts.content:
You Might Be Surprised…

You’ve had a great year. Invoices flying out, money coming in, the business account looks healthy. Then your accountant drops the bombshell:

“You made a £70,000 profit. Your Corporation Tax bill is due soon.”

Wait—what? You don’t have £70,000 in the bank. So how are you being taxed on that?

Welcome to the world of taxable profit—and it might not be what you think.

At Black & White Accounting Limited, we love helping business owners understand the why behind the numbers. Because when you understand how profit is calculated for Corporation Tax, you can plan smarter, spend better, and legally reduce your tax bill.

Let’s clear this up.

🧾 First, What Is Corporation Tax?

If you run a limited company, you pay Corporation Tax on your taxable profits—this includes:

  • Trading profits (what you earn from your core business)
  • Investment income (e.g. bank interest)
  • Capital gains (profit from selling company assets like vehicles or property)

As of 2023:

  • Profits up to £50,000 are taxed at 19%
  • Profits over £250,000 are taxed at 25%
  • Between £50k and £250k? You’ll fall under marginal relief, a tapered rate

📍 Your profit number isn’t just “what’s left in your bank account”—and that’s where most people get tripped up.

💡 So, What Counts as Profit?

Here’s where things get a little… surprising.

✅ INCLUDED in Taxable Profit:

1. Sales Revenue

This one’s obvious. Anything your company earns from sales, services, or fees is part of your total income.

2. Interest or Investment Income

Earned interest from business savings accounts or other investments? That counts too.

3. Grants or COVID Relief (in some cases)

Depending on the type, some grants must be included in your taxable income.

4. Gains from Selling Assets

Sell a company car or equipment at a profit? That’s a capital gain, and it’s taxable.

5. Some “Non-Cash” Gains

Things like exchange rate gains or inter-company transactions may be included even if no cash changed hands.

❌ NOT ALL EXPENSES REDUCE YOUR TAXABLE PROFIT

This is the kicker.

Even if you’ve spent money on things you thought were business-related, HMRC might disallow them.

Here are some common examples of non-deductible expenses:

🧠 Bottom line: Just because you spent it, doesn’t mean it lowers your tax bill.

🧮 Example: The Surprising Profit

Let’s say you run a small design agency.

  • Sales: £100,000
  • Business expenses (staff, rent, software): £60,000
  • Business entertainment: £2,000
  • You withdraw £20,000 as dividends

Here’s what happens:

  • Taxable Profit = £100,000 – £60,000 = £40,000
  • That £2,000 entertainment? Not deductible. So HMRC adds it back.
  • Taxable Profit = £42,000
  • Dividends? Not an expense. They’re taxed personally, not through Corporation Tax

💥 You’re taxed on more than you expected—and your cash flow might not match.

🧠 Why This Matters

If you don’t understand what HMRC considers “profit,” you could:

  • Miss opportunities to claim valid reliefs
  • Forget to plan for your Corporation Tax bill
  • Leave money on the table

This is why we always say: Tax planning is a year-round sport, not a year-end panic.

🛠️ The Tools to Get It Right

Using cloud accounting software like:

  • Xero
  • QuickBooks
  • FreeAgent
  • Sage

…can help you:

  • Track income and expenses in real time
  • Flag disallowable expenses automatically
  • See your likely tax bill before it’s due
  • Stay MTD (Making Tax Digital) compliant

At Black & White Accounting, we don’t just file your returns—we make the tools work for you.

🤝 How We Help You Stay Profitable (and Legal)

We go beyond the basics. With our team, you get:

  • ✅ Year-round tax forecasting
  • ✅ Real-time advice on spending and deductions
  • ✅ Personalised profit extraction planning
  • ✅ Support with R&D, capital allowances, and pension tax relief
  • ✅ Corporation Tax returns done right—first time, every time

🚀 Final Thought: Know What You’re Really Earning

Profit isn’t just what’s left in the account—it’s what HMRC decides you earned.

With Black & White Accounting Limited in your corner, you’ll know exactly where you stand, what counts, and how to pay less tax legally.

posts.content:
Don’t Panic. Don’t Ignore It. Here’s How to Take Back Control—Fast.

So, a brown envelope from HMRC just landed on your doormat—or worse, your inbox pinged with “Self-Assessment Enquiry”.

Your stomach drops. Your palms sweat. Your mind races…

“Did I do something wrong?”
“Is this a full-blown investigation?”
“Am I in trouble?”

Take a deep breath. Because this doesn’t have to be scary.

At Black & White Accounting Limited, we help business owners, landlords, freelancers and directors respond to HMRC enquiries with confidence, clarity, and calm.

Here’s what to do next.

❓What Is an HMRC Self-Assessment Enquiry?

An enquiry simply means HMRC is taking a closer look at your Self-Assessment tax return. That’s it.

It doesn’t automatically mean they think you’re guilty of anything—just that something has triggered further review.

It could be:

  • A mismatch with third-party data (e.g. banks, letting agents, payment platforms)
  • A return filed late or with missing details
  • High-value claims or expenses
  • Random selection as part of routine checks

It might be a quick clarification. Or it could be more in-depth.

Either way, ignoring it is the worst move. But we can help you respond the right way.

🧾 What Might HMRC Ask For?

Depending on the scope of the enquiry, they may request:

  • Copies of invoices, receipts or bank statements
  • Proof of expenses or deductions claimed
  • Rental income breakdowns
  • Business mileage logs
  • Crypto transaction history
  • Dividend vouchers or director loan account details
  • Written explanations for unusual figures

✅ Good records = smoother resolution.
Don’t have everything? We’ll help you rebuild and respond.

⏳ How Long Do You Have to Reply?

Typically, HMRC gives you 30 days to respond.

The clock starts ticking from the date on the letter—not when you open it.

⏱ Miss this deadline and penalties can escalate fast.
⏱ Respond properly, and you could resolve it with no changes at all.

💥 What Happens If You Ignore It?

Honestly? Nothing good.

Failure to respond can lead to:

  • Estimated assessments (HMRC guesses your tax)
  • Fines and penalties for non-cooperation
  • Interest on additional tax owed
  • A fast track to a full-blown investigation

Don’t gamble. Get support right away.

🤝 How Black & White Accounting Can Help

We’ve helped countless clients turn scary HMRC letters into non-events. Here’s what we’ll do for you:

✅ Review the enquiry and explain what HMRC wants (plain English only!)
✅ Gather or reconstruct any records you need
✅ Draft your official response
✅ Communicate with HMRC on your behalf
✅ Negotiate time extensions or reduced penalties (if needed)
✅ Advise on future-proofing your returns

Our mission? To protect you, your business, and your peace of mind.

🧠 How to Reduce the Risk of Future Enquiries

💡 File accurately
💡 Keep great records
💡 Don’t claim dodgy deductions
💡 Get an accountant who knows what they’re doing (👋 Hi there)

And if you’re not 100% confident in your past returns—we can review them before HMRC ever does.

🏁 Final Word: An Enquiry Isn’t the End—It’s Just the Start of the Conversation

HMRC letters don’t have to mean panic. With the right support, they mean paperwork, not punishment.

If you’ve received an enquiry—or even just a cryptic email from HMRC—get in touch today. The sooner we act, the smoother the solution.

posts.content:
The Truth: It’s Not About Paperwork—It’s About Getting Paid to Innovate

You’ve spent time, money and brainpower building something new.
Maybe you hired developers, tested new recipes, trialled eco-packaging, or wrestled with technical roadblocks.

Guess what? You might be sitting on thousands of pounds in R&D tax credits.

But there’s one catch:

If your records are weak, your claim could sink.
If they’re solid? 💥 HMRC pays—and fast.

At Black & White Accounting Limited, we turn technical innovation into tax relief every single day. And the difference between an average claim and a great one? The right records.

Here’s your insider guide to what you really need—and how to stay claim-ready all year long.

🧾 First—What Is an R&D Tax Credit?

A quick refresher:

R&D tax credits reward UK limited companies that invest in innovation—developing new or improved:

  • Products
  • Processes
  • Services
  • Software
  • Materials

If you’ve spent money trying to solve a technical or scientific challenge, you can claim back up to 27% of those costs—even if the project didn’t succeed.

📋 The 6 Types of Records That Strengthen Your Claim

To make your claim HMRC-proof (and maximise your return), these are the records you need:

1. 🛠 Project Records & Technical Notes

Your R&D story starts here.

✅ What was the problem you were trying to solve?
✅ What technical uncertainty did you face?
✅ What did you try, test, fail, and finally achieve?
✅ Why wasn’t the solution obvious or already known?

📌 These notes can come from:

  • Project management tools (Asana, Trello, Jira)
  • Emails between developers, designers, or engineers
  • Tech specs, whiteboards, and dev logs
  • Meeting minutes or sprint plans

Top tip: You don’t need glossy reports. Just capture what was done and why it was difficult.

2. ⏱️ Staff Timesheets or Role Summaries

HMRC wants to know who did the work—and how much of their time was R&D.

✅ Timesheets
✅ Task logs
✅ Weekly summaries
✅ Estimated % breakdown of R&D vs admin/support work

This is crucial for claiming:

  • Staff salaries
  • Employer NIC
  • Pension contributions

Even directors and part-time team members can be included.

3. 📑 Payroll & Cost Data

You’ll need to back up salary claims with payroll records:

  • Payslips
  • RTI submissions
  • Contracts
  • Payroll journals

Also keep evidence of pension contributions or bonuses linked to R&D projects.

Pro tip: Cloud payroll systems (like Xero or QuickBooks) make this super simple—we’ll help you extract what HMRC wants to see.

4. 💸 Invoices & Purchase Records

You can claim for:

  • Subcontractors
  • Software licences
  • Cloud hosting
  • Materials for prototypes
  • Testing and consultancy fees

Make sure you keep:

  • Supplier invoices
  • Bank statements or proof of payment
  • Agreements with freelancers or agencies

If you paid someone to help solve a technical problem—they may be claimable.

5. ☁️ Software & Cloud Costs

Using AWS, Azure, GCP or similar for testing and development?
Paying for Figma, GitHub, CAD tools, or specialist design platforms?

✅ Keep:

  • Invoices
  • Subscription records
  • Screenshots of usage reports if possible

HMRC increasingly wants to see usage linked to specific projects—so flag those costs clearly.

6. 📆 Timelines & Milestones

Good R&D claims tell a story over time. You’ll want:

  • Start/end dates for each project
  • Milestone charts
  • Launch or release dates
  • Logs of testing rounds or iterations

These help us show HMRC that the work evolved and required investment—not a one-day job.

📉 What Happens If You Don’t Have Great Records?

  • Claims may be reduced
  • HMRC may challenge or delay your refund
  • You could miss out on thousands in eligible costs
  • In worst cases—claims get rejected or trigger an enquiry

Let’s not go there. We’ll help you get it right.

🤖 How to Make Record-Keeping Easier (and Automatic)

Use smart tools that save time and keep you audit-ready:

✅ Xero/QuickBooks/Sage/FreeAgent – for payroll and expenses
✅ Project management tools – to track tasks and timelines
✅ Google Drive/Dropbox/Notion – to store meeting notes or dev logs
✅ Time-tracking apps – like Clockify, Harvest, or built-in tools
✅ Slack/email threads – for conversations that capture the challenge

No need to over-engineer it. Just be consistent—and let us do the heavy lifting.

🤝 How Black & White Accounting Helps You Win at R&D

We:

  • ✅ Extract claimable costs from your accounts and software
  • ✅ Interview your team to capture your R&D story
  • ✅ Build technical reports HMRC loves
  • ✅ Maximise your claim—while staying 100% compliant
  • ✅ Handle everything from claim to cash in your account

You innovate. We document and deliver the rebate.

🏁 Final Word: Good Records = Bigger Claims, Faster Payouts

Don’t let poor paperwork shrink your R&D refund.
With smart systems and expert support, your claim can be quick, compliant and cash-generating.

You’re already doing the hard work. Now let’s make sure you get paid for it.

posts.title: What exemptions from Making Tax Digital for Income Tax (MTD IT) the HM Revenue & Customs will accept
posts.excerpt: At Black & White Accounting, we pride ourselves on staying ahead of the curve so that you don’t have to. With the announcement from HMRC that applications are now open for exemptions on the grounds of digital exclusion, now is the time for sole traders and landlords to act, seek clarity, and if necessary, secure […]
posts.content:
At Black & White Accounting, we pride ourselves on staying ahead of the curve so that you don’t have to. With the announcement from HMRC that applications are now open for exemptions on the grounds of digital exclusion, now is the time for sole traders and landlords to act, seek clarity, and if necessary, secure their exemption from MTD IT. Here’s a full breakdown of what you need to know.

📣 Big news: Exemption applications now open

HMRC has recently confirmed that individuals who believe they’re digitally excluded can now apply for an exemption from MTD for Income Tax. In summary:

  • From 6 April 2026, individuals with qualifying income (self-employment or property) over £50,000 will have to use MTD for Income Tax.
  • From 6 April 2027, the threshold drops to £30,000.
  • From 6 April 2028, it will be £20,000 (for the 2026-27 year) as law is extended.
  • But if you can demonstrate digital exclusion, you may be exempt from using the MTD digital system.

So, if you’re reading this and thinking: “Am I going to have to switch to digital reporting next year?”; the answer is likely yes, unless an exemption applies to you. And that’s where we step in.

✅ What kinds of scenarios will HMRC accept for exemption

HMRC defines “digitally excluded” as cases where “it’s not reasonably practicable” to use compatible software and keep digital records. Examples cited include:

  • A taxpayer’s age, health condition or disability means they cannot use a computer/tablet/smartphone/software.
  • The taxpayer lives in a location where internet access is unavailable or unsuitable, and no suitable alternative location is reasonably accessible.
  • A practising member of a religious society or order whose beliefs are incompatible with using electronic communications or keeping electronic records.

Importantly: HMRC says that the taxpayer must show how their personal circumstances make digital compliance not reasonably practicable, not just inconvenient.

🚫 What situations HMRC will not accept

Being clear about these will help you decide whether an exemption application is credible, and how we at Black & White Accounting can help you build that case:

HMRC guidance states that the following alone will not qualify for exemption:

  • Simply because you have always filed a paper tax return in the past.
  • You are unfamiliar with accountancy software – because unfamiliarity alone does not make digital reporting “not reasonably practicable”.
  • You only have a small number of digital records to create each year.
  • It will cost extra time or extra money for you to sign up for and use MTD-software (unless that cost is combined with other factors like disability, remoteness, etc).

In short: HMRC expects you to make a strong case. If you simply dislike or find digital systems inconvenient, you won’t likely qualify.

🧾 How to apply to be exempt – and how we help you

Here is the application process, step by step – and where Black & White Accounting can take the lead to support you all the way.

Step 1: Check whether you need to use MTD for Income Tax

  • Work out if you’re within the thresholds (over £50,000 from April 2026, £30,000 from April 2027, £20,000 from April 2028) for self-employment/property income.
  • If you’re below the threshold, you aren’t yet mandated,  but you may opt in early.
  • If you are above, then prepare to join MTD unless you secure a valid exemption.

How Black & White helps: We’ll review your income streams and projections, confirm your threshold status, and advise whether you’re in scope and therefore likely to need either to comply or to consider an exemption.

Step 2: Decide if you have genuine grounds for “digital exclusion”

  • Review whether any of your personal circumstances match HMRC’s examples: health/disability, poor internet access or geographical remoteness, religious beliefs.
  • Gather evidence: perhaps a statement of access issues, medical reports, religious society membership, or combinations thereof.

How we help: We’ll assist you in assessing your circumstances against HMRC’s criteria, pull together supporting documentation, and formulate the narrative why MTD is not reasonably practicable for you.

Step 3: Submit the application to HMRC

  • The application must be made before you are required to use MTD. HMRC aims to respond within 28 days.
  • Application can be made by phone or writing to HMRC (Self Assessment general enquiries). The letter should be headed: “Making Tax Digital for Income Tax – digitally excluded application”.
  • You’ll need to provide: your National Insurance number, name, address; how you currently submit your tax return; whether you use an agent (and what they do); your reasons and supporting information; details of any additional needs.

How we help: We will draft or review the letter/application, ensure all details are accurate, liaise with HMRC (if authorised) and monitor the process so you don’t miss deadlines or required follow-up.

Step 4: After applying – what happens next?

  • HMRC will issue a decision letter. If approved, you may continue submitting Self Assessment returns (paper or non-MTD digital) instead of joining the quarterly MTD updates.
  • If HMRC rejects, you have 30 days from the date on the letter to appeal.
  • Even while you wait for HMRC’s response, you should still prepare as though you may have to join MTD, keeping your records up to date and software ready.
  • If your circumstances change (for instance, your disability improves or internet access becomes available) you must notify HMRC, because your exemption may no longer apply.

How we help: We’ll keep you on track with deadlines, manage your record-keeping whether you’re joining MTD or awaiting an exemption decision, and assist with the appeal if required.

🌟 Why choose Black & White Accounting as your partner

  • We’re a fast-growing firm with a dynamic approach: we bring the latest regulatory updates (such as this MTD IT exemption) to our clients proactively.
  • We specialise in helping small business owners, sole traders and landlords – the very groups most impacted by MTD IT.
  • We take the hassle off your plate: from eligibility assessments and income-threshold reviews, to compiling supporting evidence, drafting the exemption application, liaising with HMRC, and preparing you for either scenario (compliance or exemption).
  • Whether you apply for exemption or move into full MTD-compliance, we provide ongoing support so you’re never left navigating unfamiliar software or new processes alone.
  • We believe in clarity, responsiveness and practical advice: no frightening jargon, just a clear path forward.

🔍 Final thoughts

The rollout of MTD for Income Tax is one of the biggest shifts in UK tax-admin for sole traders and landlords in many years. Being prepared matters. While the introduction of digital-recording and quarterly updates is the norm for most, the availability of exemption on grounds of digital exclusion gives a crucial lifeline for those whose circumstances genuinely make the digital route impractical.

If you think you might qualify for the exemption, or even if you’re unsure and want reassurance, now is the time to act.

At Black & White Accounting, we’re ready to help you every step of the way: from checking whether you’re in scope, reviewing your circumstances for digital exclusion, to applying for exemption or guiding you seamlessly into MTD-compliance.

👉 Get in touch with us today, and let’s make sure your tax-journey is as smooth and stress-free as possible.

Let’s turn the unknown into “done and dusted”.

posts.content:
If you thought budgeting is only about bean counting, think again. The upcoming Autumn Budget is shaping up to be one of the most consequential and closely watched in recent years – especially for businesses, investors, and high-net-worth individuals. And as a dynamic, growth-driven accountancy firm, this is exactly the kind of event we live for.

In this post, we’ll walk through:

  1. What the Budget is (in case any clients ask!)
  2. When it will happen
  3. The big tax, spending, and policy changes potentially in the air
  4. What your business or personal finances should be bracing for
  5. What we (as your accountants) will be doing ahead of, during, and after the event

What is the Budget (and why it matters)

At its heart, the Budget is the Chancellor’s blueprint for how the UK raises taxes and spends money over the coming year (or years). It’s the moment when policy meets politics: tax thresholds, reliefs, spending priorities, welfare, investment incentives; almost everything in the public finances gets at least a glance.

For businesses, the Budget is a potential pivot point. New tax burdens, changes in deductions, tweaks to compliance and enforcement; all of this can shift your planning, cash flow, and investment choices.

In short: it’s not just for economists and politicians. It’s for you.

When is the 2025 Budget?

Mark your calendar now: 26 November 2025 is the date the Chancellor, Rachel Reeves, will deliver the Autumn Budget to the House of Commons.

That date gives us a runway, but not a lot of slack. The lead-up period will be full of leaks, speculation, and shifting market expectations.

What’s in Play: Key Areas to Watch

The headlines are already filling up with speculation about what might change. Below is a curated view of the most plausible and impactful shifts we’re watching (and telling our clients to watch). However, these are still speculative, we will not know until the Chancellor enters the dispatches box exactly what is coming.

1. Tax thresholds – “stealth tax” through freezes

One of the favourites for raising revenue without headline rate hikes is simply freezing thresholds for longer. As wages and inflation push income higher, more people move into higher tax bands (fiscal drag). Analysts expect the freezes on personal allowance, higher rate thresholds, and possibly the Inheritance Tax (IHT) thresholds to be extended.

2. Tweaks to reliefs, loopholes & pension rules

Rather than hitting headline rates, the Treasury may go after reliefs:

  • Restricting the tax and National Insurance advantages of salary sacrifice schemes
  • Limiting higher-rate reliefs on pension contributions
  • Reforming or capping exemptions (e.g. on capital gains, residence reliefs)
  • “Closing loopholes” in property or other niches (often framed as fairness rather than new taxation)

3. Property & real-estate taxes

The property sector is under the spotlight. Some possibilities under discussion:

  • Bringing property income (i.e. certain landlord rental income) into the scope of National Insurance contributions
  • Reforming Stamp Duty Land Tax (SDLT) or replacing it with a seller’s tax on high-value properties
  • Adjusting Private Residence Relief (PRR) in high-value cases, perhaps capping it over a certain value or aligning CGT and income tax rates
  • New council tax bands, revaluation, or more aggressive taxation of second homes

These changes can carry knock-on effects; fewer properties listed, market uncertainty, and shifts in investor behaviour.

4. Personal & wealth taxes

Given pressures on public finances, there’s talk of:

  • An explicit wealth tax (though this is politically and administratively tricky)
  • Reducing the 25% tax-free pension lump sum or capping it for higher-value individuals
  • Aligning CGT rates more closely with income tax for gains above thresholds
  • Tightening Inheritance Tax reliefs and possibly extending the gift-giving rules (e.g. lifetime caps, cumulation rules)

5. Business & corporation tax

While the government has committed (so far) not to increase the headline corporation tax rate (currently 25%), there is still room to tinker around the edges:

  • Adjusting surcharge rates (e.g. for banks)
  • Reducing the threshold for VAT registration or increasing the sectors it applies to
  • Tightening rules on deductions, capital allowances, or R&D incentives
  • Compliance changes, penalty reforms, and more aggressive enforcement

Even without a rate hike, a small adjustment to surcharges or reliefs can meaningfully impact tax bills.

6. Spending, public services & investment

On the spending side, many expect:

  • Further pressures on welfare budgets, eligibility criteria or benefit elements (though politically sensitive)
  • More capital investment — especially in infrastructure, green energy, technology, or regional growth zones (consistent with Labour’s “modern supply-side” agenda)
  • A push to maintain or increase public service funding (health, education) to match Labour’s manifesto commitments
  • A need to balance growth and fairness in the narrative — tax rises must be justified as fair or targeted

What Might Rock Your Boat: Impacts & Risks

Some of the likely outcomes (and risks) that our clients should start planning for:

  • Cash flow shock: If new liabilities (or reduced reliefs) are introduced retrospectively or mid-year, businesses may face surprises
  • Investment decisions: Capital tie-ups, expansions, or M&A plans could be altered or delayed until after the dust settles
  • Property investors & landlords: Any change in how property income or gains are taxed can mean higher costs, or changes in strategy (sell vs hold)
  • Individual tax planning: High net worth individuals or those near thresholds must reassess pension strategies, gifting, capital gains timing
  • Administrative burden: More compliance, tighter rules, more HMRC scrutiny, the hidden cost of “fixing loopholes” is often compliance overhead
  • Market & sentiment risk: Investors, lenders and markets respond to uncertainty. A “bad” or aggressive budget could dampen confidence

On the flip side, there may be opportunities:

  • Reliefs or incentives in areas the government wants to promote (R&D, green, regional investment)
  • Restructuring or reorganising assets ahead of changes
  • Locking in favourable rates or treatments before they expire
  • Early assessment of capital gains, pension allowances or gifting to reduce exposure

The Big Question: Will It Be “Painful”?

Short answer: probably. The government is facing tighter public finances, higher borrowing costs, and pressures to meet its own fiscal rules. The fantasy of raising large new revenues without cost or friction is unlikely to survive the scrutiny of markets and politics.

That said, the framing matters. If the Chancellor can thread a narrative of fairness, investment and growth, she may soften blowback. We do expect some tax rises or relief reductions, but likely with targeted exemptions or phased implementation to reduce political backlash.

 How Black & White Accounting Will Support You

At Black & White Accounting, we know that budgets aren’t just about headline numbers, they’re about how those changes flow through to your business, your family, and your future.

Our approach is simple: we cut through the jargon and give you clear, actionable advice that helps you make confident decisions. Whether it’s re-structuring your business for tax efficiency, planning ahead for changes to allowances, or making sure you don’t miss opportunities hidden in the detail, we’ll be by your side.

As a dynamic, fast-growing practice, we’re “big enough to know and small enough to care”, which means we’ll stay ahead of the detail while keeping our advice tailored to your unique circumstances.

Thank you for reading and you know where we are if you have any burning questions at this stage. If you are not already signed up to our newsletter, please join up today [here].
