posts.content:
Don’t Let Second Jobs Create First-Class Headaches

So, your new hire has another job.
Or maybe a side hustle. Or two.

No big deal… until it is.

If your employee has more than one job, it doesn’t just affect them—it affects you too. From tax codes to NI contributions, getting PAYE wrong can lead to underpayments, overpayments, HMRC letters, and confused staff.

At Black & White Accounting Limited, we help employers keep payroll clean, compliant, and crystal clear—even when your team has a few extra gigs on the side.

Here’s what you need to know to stay on the right side of PAYE—and keep your employees happy and HMRC off your back.

💼 First, Yes—People Can Have More Than One Job

It’s completely legal and increasingly common for employees to:

  • Work two part-time roles
  • Hold a job and run a self-employed business
  • Have multiple PAYE jobs (e.g. hospitality or gig work)

But when you become one of those employers, PAYE rules still apply—and the setup might not be as simple as you think.

🧾 The Key Issues for Employers

1. Tax Code Confusion

This is the big one.

When someone has multiple PAYE jobs:

  • HMRC usually applies the full personal allowance (£12,570) to just one job
  • The other(s) will use a basic rate code (BR, D0 or D1)—which means all pay is taxed at 20%, 40%, or 45%

If your payroll system applies the wrong tax code, your employee might:

  • Overpay tax (and get grumpy)
  • Underpay tax (and face a nasty bill later)

🧠 What you need to do:

  • Always use the tax code HMRC gives you (via a P45 or starter checklist)
  • Don’t try to guess or “help” by assigning the full allowance unless you’re told to
  • If no tax code is provided, follow the starter checklist rules to assign the correct temporary code

2. National Insurance Contributions (NIC)

Here’s the twist:
NIC is calculated per job—not per person.

So if your employee has two jobs:

  • They could end up paying NI twice on earnings below the threshold
  • HMRC may issue a refund—but months later

🧠 What you need to do:
You can’t avoid this—it’s how the system works. But you can:

  • Inform your employee that NICs are per employer
  • Suggest they contact HMRC for a refund if they’ve overpaid

3. Student Loans and Other Deductions

Student loan repayments, Postgraduate Loans, and even Scottish tax codes are applied across all employment income—so it’s important each job uses the correct flag.

If you forget to tick the student loan box during setup:

  • Your employee may underpay
  • HMRC may demand a correction later—through your payroll

🧠 Pro Tip: Always complete the starter checklist carefully—it includes student loan status.

4. Benefits and Threshold-Based Triggers

Your employee’s second job might push them:

  • Over the pension auto-enrolment threshold
  • Over the NIC primary threshold
  • Into a higher tax band than expected
  • Into student loan repayment territory

🧠 What you need to do:
Run your payroll as normal, based only on what they earn with you.
But advise your team to track their combined income and plan ahead. We’re happy to work directly with your employees if they need help managing this.

✅ How to Set It Up Right (From Day One)

Step 1: Collect the Right Info

  • P45 from their previous job (if it’s replacing one)
  • Starter Checklist if this is a second/additional job

Step 2: Follow the Instructions

  • Use HMRC’s guidance on which tax code to apply
  • If unsure, assign emergency tax code and update once HMRC confirms

Step 3: Submit Real-Time Information (RTI) to HMRC

  • Every time you run payroll, you submit a Full Payment Submission (FPS)
  • HMRC tracks income across all jobs to ensure compliance

💡 Don’t guess tax codes—wait for HMRC’s notice (via PAYE Online or post).

🤖 Why Cloud Payroll Software Helps

With tools like Xero, QuickBooks, Sage, and FreeAgent, you can:

  • Import correct tax codes from HMRC
  • Run multiple job setups without mistakes
  • Track pay, deductions, and pension eligibility in real time
  • Create clear payslips and submit accurate RTI reports

And with Black & White Accounting managing your payroll, you won’t have to worry about a thing.

🤝 How We Help Employers Get It Right

Whether your team includes full-timers, freelancers, or part-timers with second jobs, we help you:

  • ✅ Register and set up PAYE properly
  • ✅ Handle P45s, starter checklists, and tax code changes
  • ✅ Run compliant payroll every month (or week)
  • ✅ Manage pensions, NICs, and student loans
  • ✅ Avoid penalties, overpayments, or under-reporting

We keep you compliant, confident, and focused on growth—not red tape.

🚀 Final Word: Second Jobs, First-Class Payroll

You don’t need to understand every tax code nuance—but you do need to run PAYE the right way.

Your employees trust you to get it right. HMRC expects nothing less. And when you’ve got the right accountant by your side, PAYE becomes a system that works for you—not against you.

posts.title: The Companies House Revolution Arrives 18 November 2025 — Are You Ready?
posts.excerpt: In the fast-paced world of business, change is the only constant. But every so often, a regulatory shift comes along so profound that it demands attention and proactive preparation. The Companies House reforms set to begin on 18 November 2025 are exactly that kind of shift. At Black & White Accounting, we believe in not […]
posts.content:
In the fast-paced world of business, change is the only constant. But every so often, a regulatory shift comes along so profound that it demands attention and proactive preparation. The Companies House reforms set to begin on 18 November 2025 are exactly that kind of shift.

At Black & White Accounting, we believe in not just keeping pace, but staying ahead. Here’s what’s changing, why it matters, and how we will guide you through the new landscape.

What Is Changing?

The Companies House reforms stem from the Economic Crime and Corporate Transparency Act 2023 (ECCTA), designed to modernise UK corporate registers, tighten anti-fraud controls, and dramatically raise transparency standards.

From 18 November 2025, four core changes take effect:

  1. Mandatory Identity Verification (IDV)
    • Every new director and new Person with Significant Control (PSC) must verify their identity before incorporation or appointment.
    • Existing directors and PSCs must verify their identity within a 12-month transition period, typically aligned with their next confirmation statement.
  2. Abolition of Some Statutory Registers
    • From 18 November 2025, companies will no longer be legally required to keep registers of:
      • Directors
      • Directors’ residential addresses
      • Secretaries
      • PSCs
    • Instead, those details will be maintained centrally by Companies House.
    • Companies will still need to maintain a register of shareholders (members), either at the registered office or a single alternative inspection location (SAIL).
  3. Tighter Control on Who Can File on Your Behalf
    • Only verified individuals (i.e. those who have passed ID verification) or Authorised Corporate Service Providers (ACSPs) will be able to file documents with Companies House.
    • To act as an ACSP, a firm must register with Companies House and comply with anti-money laundering (AML) supervision.
  4. Other Reforms in the Pipeline (Coming Shortly After)
    • While not in force on 18 November, the shift toward requiring all companies to file via commercial accounting software is scheduled to begin in April 2027. This change will replace paper and web-based submissions altogether.
    • From 2027, many companies that currently file abridged accounts will no longer be allowed to do so; profit & loss figures, directors’ reports, and fuller disclosure become the norm.

In short: from late 2025, identity verification and register simplification hit first; by 2027, the full digital transformation of reporting follows. There has been speculation that the future reforms could be reformed, but this has not been announced yet. Rest assured if there are any changes, we will update you as soon as they are announced.

Why Is This Change Happening?

This overhaul isn’t arbitrary, it’s part of a bold mission to rein in economic crime, restore trust in the UK’s company registry, and bring the system into the digital age.

  • Combat fraud and shell companies
      For years, weak verification has allowed entities to register under false names or addresses (think “Darth Vader Ltd.”). The new rules aim to close that loophole.
  • Improve data quality, consistency, and reliability
      By centralising and verifying key officer information, Companies House can reduce errors, standardise formats, and make the register more trustworthy.
  • Simplify corporate administration
      Removing redundant internal registers and consolidating statutory data handling should reduce duplication.
  • Modernise and digitise reporting
      The shift toward mandatory use of commercial accounting software is intended to reduce fraud risk, standardise submissions, and streamline operations.
  • Support enforcement powers
      The reforms give Companies House sharper powers to query, challenge, reject, or strike filings that don’t comply, making the regime more resilient to misuse.

In short: to bring the UK registry into the digital age, raise the bar on accountability, and reduce the shadow economy of fraudulent corporate entities.

The Risk of Doing Nothing

This isn’t a “nice to have”, non-compliance carries real consequences, potentially including:

  • Filings may be rejected or voided if submitted by unverified individuals
  • Companies & officers risk penalties, annotations, or restrictions
  • Where filings are invalidated, corporate actions (changes of director, share issues, etc.) could collapse
  • In extreme cases, non-compliance might impact a company’s legal standing or its ability to act

Moreover, data from Vistra suggests that only 28% of UK directors were “ready” for the reforms as of mid-2025, leaving a huge proportion exposed to last-minute scramble. Vistra

How Black & White Accounting Will Help You Ride the Change

At Black & White Accounting, we see this transition not as a burden, but as an opportunity; for stronger compliance, smoother operations, and clearer assurance. Here’s how we’ll support our clients every step of the way:

1. Proactive Identity Verification Assistance

We’ll guide your directors and PSCs through the verification process, whether via GOV.UK’s One Login method or via our status as an Authorised Corporate Service Provider (ACSP).
We’ll manage the logistics, ensure proper documentation, and monitor deadlines — so no one gets left behind.

2. Registration as Your ACSP

Black & White is preparing to become a registered ACSP. That means we can handle identity verification and statutory filings on your behalf, licensed by law, supervised under AML rules, and fully compliant with Companies House requirements.

3. Register Review & Transition Support

We’ll assess your company’s existing statutory registers and prepare for the transition to the new regime (e.g. migration or archiving of redundant registers).
We’ll also ensure your shareholder (member) register is correctly held and maintained in compliance with the SAIL or registered office requirement.

4. Filing Controls & Quality Assurance

Once filings can only be made by verified individuals or ACSPs, the margin for error narrows. We’ll build robust internal checks, ensure identity-verified filers carry out submissions, and guard against rejection or non-compliance.

5. Training & Communication

We’ll offer workshops, guides, and tailored advice to educate company directors, secretarial teams, and stakeholders in your organisation about what’s changing, when, and how to comply.

6. Forward Planning for 2027 Changes

We’re already preparing clients for the second wave of reforms — especially the transition to software-only filing and expanded disclosure obligations. With Black & White as your partner, you won’t be scrambling, you’ll be ready.

Final Word: Don’t Wait for the Deadline

Regulatory upheaval can feel daunting, but it’s also a moment to reinforce trust, modernise your operations, and strengthen your compliance posture.

From 18 November 2025, identity verification becomes non-negotiable. But with foresight and partnership, like that offered by Black & White Accounting, you can turn this challenge into an opportunity to shine.

Let’s get you ready. Let’s get you ahead.

posts.content:
The next big milestone in digital tax reporting is here, and it’s set to transform how landlords manage their property finances. Making Tax Digital (MTD) has been making waves for several years, and now it’s landlords’ turn to get on board. But don’t worry,  with the right preparation (and the right accounting partner!), this change can be smooth, efficient, and even beneficial.

At Black & White Accounting, we’re here to help landlords, and the estate and letting agents who support them, understand exactly what’s coming, why it matters, and how to make it work in your favour.

📜 A Quick History of Making Tax Digital (MTD)

The UK government launched the Making Tax Digital initiative back in 2019, starting with VAT. The goal? To make the tax system more efficient, accurate, and easier to manage by reducing paperwork and embracing digital tools.

Since then, MTD has rolled out to VAT-registered businesses and will soon extend to self-employed individuals and landlords with income over £50,000 from April 2026 (and those earning over £30,000 by 2027).

In short, MTD is here to stay, and it’s reshaping the way individuals and businesses interact with HMRC.

💡 So, What Exactly Is MTD?

MTD means that instead of submitting one annual Self Assessment tax return, landlords will need to digitally record their property income and expenses and submit quarterly updates to HMRC through approved accounting software.

This means no more piles of receipts, no more last-minute scrambles in January, and fewer errors. Everything will be recorded digitally, giving landlords a clearer, more up-to-date picture of their finances year-round.

🎯 The Goal of MTD – Why It’s Happening

The government’s aim with MTD is simple:

  • Accuracy: Reduce mistakes in tax reporting (currently costing HMRC billions each year).
  • Transparency: Give taxpayers real-time visibility of their financial position and tax liability.
  • Efficiency: Streamline communication between taxpayers and HMRC.

For landlords, this means less guesswork, more control, and the ability to make informed financial decisions throughout the year, not just at tax time.

🏘️ What This Means for Landlords

If you earn more than £50,000 in annual gross property income from 2026 (or £30,000 from 2027), you’ll need to:

  1. Keep digital records of all property income and expenses.
  2. Submit quarterly updates to HMRC via MTD-compatible software.
  3. Submit an end-of-period statement (EOPS) and a final declaration each year.

If you have multiple properties, you’ll need to record and report the details of each, and if you’re both self-employed and a landlord, you’ll need to do this for each source of income.

Sounds like a lot? It doesn’t have to be, not with the right systems in place.

🧭 What Landlords Need to Do Now

  1. Get organised early. Start digitising your records now, so you’re not rushing in 2026.
  2. Choose the right software. You’ll need MTD-compliant accounting software to keep records and file updates.
  3. Understand your reporting requirements. We can help you determine whether you’re in the first wave (2026) or second (2027).
  4. Talk to your accountant. The sooner you prepare, the easier it’ll be to stay compliant, and stress-free.

⚙️ How Black & White Accounting Can Help – Every Step of the Way

At Black & White Accounting, we’re not just keeping up with MTD, we’re leading the charge. Here’s how we’ll help you get MTD-ready:

✅ MTD software setup & training – We’ll help you choose and implement the best software for your needs (and show you how to use it).
✅ Digital recordkeeping & bookkeeping support – We can manage as much (or as little) as you’d like.
✅ Quarterly submissions – Never miss a deadline, we’ll handle the updates for you.
✅ Strategic tax planning – With real-time data, we can help you make smarter financial decisions.
✅ Agent partnership support – We work with estate and letting agents to help their clients stay compliant, organised, and informed.

Our goal is simple: to make sure landlords, and the professionals who support them, are confident, compliant, and future-ready.

🚀 MTD 2026 and Beyond – Let’s Get You Ready

2026 might seem a while away, but in the world of tax and compliance, preparation is everything. Start your MTD journey now, and you’ll thank yourself later.

Whether you manage one property or a whole portfolio, Black & White Accounting is here to simplify the process, every step of the way.

📩 Get in touch today to find out how we can help you and your clients prepare for Making Tax Digital for Landlords.

posts.content:
Smash Your Profits—Not Your Peace of Mind

If you’ve got a limited company, then you’ve got a date with HMRC every year. It’s called Corporation Tax—and understanding it could be the difference between smart growth and nasty surprises.

At Black & White Accounting Limited, we love turning financial jargon into clear, actionable advice. So whether you’re a first-time founder or scaling up fast, this blog gives you the lowdown on what Corporation Tax is, when it applies, and how to stay ahead of the game.

Let’s break it down.

🧾 What Is Corporation Tax?

Corporation Tax is a tax paid by limited companies on their taxable profits. Think of it as the business version of Income Tax.

Profits can come from:

  • Trading (selling goods or services)
  • Investments
  • Asset sales (like selling property or shares)

🧠 Sole traders don’t pay Corporation Tax—they pay Income Tax through Self Assessment. This only applies to limited companies.

💼 How Much Is Corporation Tax?

As of April 2023, Corporation Tax is no longer one fixed rate. Here’s the deal:

💡 Tip: If your business is connected to others (e.g. part of a group), those thresholds are shared across the group!

🧮 How Do You Calculate Corporation Tax?

Here’s a simplified breakdown:

  1. Start with your company’s profit (after business expenses)
  2. Adjust for things HMRC doesn’t allow (e.g. client entertainment, non-business costs)
  3. Apply the correct tax rate
  4. Subtract any reliefs, losses or allowances (more on that below)

📍 Your Corporation Tax is based on your company’s accounting year, not the calendar year.

📆 When and How Do You Pay?

Key deadlines:

  • Tax Return (CT600): Due 12 months after your accounting period ends
  • Corporation Tax payment: Due 9 months and 1 day after your year-end
    • So if your year ends 31 March 2025, you must pay by 1 January 2026

⚠️ There are penalties for filing late, even if you don’t owe anything. So don’t risk it.

📉 Can You Reduce Your Corporation Tax Bill?

Absolutely. That’s where we come in 😎

Here are some common ways to reduce your bill:

✅ Claiming All Allowable Expenses

From tools and travel to software subscriptions and mobile phones—if it’s wholly and exclusively for business, it could be deductible.

✅ Capital Allowances

Bought equipment, vehicles or computers? You might be able to claim 100% in the year you buy it.

✅ R&D Tax Credits

Are you developing new products, systems or software? You could claim R&D tax relief, which significantly reduces your Corporation Tax—or even leads to a cash rebate.

✅ Director’s Salary & Dividends

Pay yourself wisely. The right mix of salary and dividends can reduce both your personal and company tax bill.

✅ Pension Contributions

Employer pension contributions are tax-deductible and great for long-term planning.

We help clients build a year-round tax strategy, not just fire-fight at year-end.

💻 MTD for Corporation Tax—Coming Soon!

Making Tax Digital (MTD) for Corporation Tax is on the horizon, expected to kick in in 2026.

This will mean:

  • Keeping digital records
  • Submitting updates via HMRC-approved software
  • Possibly more frequent reporting (like VAT and income tax)

Now’s the time to future-proof your business with tools like:

  • Xero
  • QuickBooks
  • FreeAgent
  • Sage

We’ll set you up, show you how to use them—or take it all off your hands!

🧠 Why This Matters

You work hard to grow your business. The last thing you want is to:

  • Miss a deadline and pay a penalty
  • Overpay because you didn’t know your allowances
  • Get investigated by HMRC because of a dodgy return

Smart Corporation Tax planning = more profit, less stress.

🚀 How Black & White Accounting Can Help

We make Corporation Tax planning simple, strategic and completely tailored to you.

With us, you get:

  • ✅ Annual accounts and Corporation Tax returns done right
  • ✅ Year-round advice on how to reduce your tax bill
  • ✅ Guidance on salary/dividend strategy
  • ✅ Access to the best cloud software (we’ll set it up)
  • ✅ Support with R&D claims, pension planning, and more
  • ✅ Total peace of mind—because we handle HMRC so you don’t have to

📢 Final Word: Get Ahead of the Tax Game

Corporation Tax doesn’t have to be scary.
With the right advice, it can become a powerful tool to grow and protect your profits.

posts.excerpt: At last, the moment we’ve been preparing for: HM Revenue & Customs has launched full-blown promotional activity around Making Tax Digital (MTD) for Income Tax Self-Assessment (MTD for ITSA) aimed at sole traders and landlords. No more “it might happen”… it is happening. It just would have been nice if the message had been louder, […]
posts.content:
At last, the moment we’ve been preparing for: HM Revenue & Customs has launched full-blown promotional activity around Making Tax Digital (MTD) for Income Tax Self-Assessment (MTD for ITSA) aimed at sole traders and landlords. No more “it might happen”… it is happening. It just would have been nice if the message had been louder, clearer, and earlier.

Here’s our take at Black & White Accounting of what’s going on, what you need to know, and how we’ll stand by you every step of the way.

What is MTD? (And what it is not)

✅ What it is

  • MTD for Income Tax Self-Assessment (ITSA) means that if you’re a sole trader or a landlord (or a similar unincorporated taxpayer) with qualifying income from self-employment and/or property, you must:
    • Keep digital records of your income and expenses (using software that is recognised by HMRC).
    • Submit quarterly updates of those digital records to HMRC.
    • At year-end, submit a final declaration (which links together the quarterly updates, your other income and reliefs).
  • It’s part of HMRC’s drive to modernise tax-administration (‘digital first’), reduce tax errors and reduce the tax-gap.
  • It already applies to VAT-registered businesses (since April 2019).

🚫 What it isn’t

  • It is not simply an optional extra for those “who want to go digital” (for those in-scope it will be mandatory).
  • It is not limited to paper plus spreadsheets. If you rely solely on manual spreadsheets without a digital link or compatible software, you’ll likely fall short.
  • It is not (for now) being mandated for all taxpayers or all business types (limited companies or partnerships might have different rules).
  • It is not only an end-of-year change. Quarter-by-quarter submissions mean tax-affairs are gradually monitored rather than just once a year.

Who is impacted?

If you’re a sole trader or landlord, you should check carefully whether you fall into the scope. Key points:

  • The threshold for ‘qualifying income’ is based on gross income from self-employment and property (before expenses and tax) for the relevant prior tax year.
  • The rollout is in phases:
    • From 6 April 2026: those with qualifying income > £50,000 will be required.
    • From 6 April 2027: those with qualifying income > £30,000.
    • From 6 April 2028: those with qualifying income > £20,000.
  • Examples: If you’re a sole trader making £55,000 self-employment income in 2024–25, you’ll likely be in-scope from April 2026. If you earn say £25,000 income (property + self-employment) you might not be mandated until April 2028.
  • Some income does not count towards the threshold (for example, PAYE employment income, dividends, etc).
  • Exemptions and deferrals may apply (if you are digitally excluded for reasons of age, disability, etc).

What it will mean for you

Here’s how your day-to-day will change, and why you shouldn’t wait until the last minute.

✔ Benefits

  • You’ll have real-time visibility of your income, expenses and likely tax bill. The new digital tools bring better cash-flow planning.
  • You reduce the risk of large year-end surprises (big tax bill, missing receipts, scrambling).
  • Your record-keeping becomes cleaner, more systematic – less “shoe-box of receipts” style. That’s good for your peace of mind and good for your accountant.
  • You and your accountant can integrate software, bank feeds, expense capture and make the process smoother.

⚠ Challenges & what to watch

  • You’ll need to adopt compatible digital software now (or imminently) and make sure workflows are set up.
  • You’ll have to submit quarterly updates (so more frequent but lighter burden – still needs discipline).
  • Because the system is more “live” there is less room for leaving everything to the end of the year.
  • Penalties will apply if you miss deadlines (and get too many points).
  • If you rely on traditional spreadsheets or paper, you may need bridging software or to move fully to a cloud system.

📅 Timeline you must keep top of mind

  • By 6 April 2026: If you are over the threshold you must have software, digital record-keeping, and be ready to submit your first quarterly update.
  • 7 August 2026: Deadline for first quarterly update for someone falling into 2026 start.
  • From 2027 onwards: More taxpayers with lower thresholds will join. So even if you’re “below now”, you’ll want to prepare ahead.
  • It’s essential to begin preparation now, not wait until the year or two before your start date.

HMRC’s Communication Plan: Who, What, How, When

Yes, the adverts are here. But what else is HMRC doing to raise awareness and help you stay ahead?

🗞 What they’re doing

  • HMRC has launched a dedicated campaign page: “Making Tax Digital for Income Tax” – explaining what it is, how it works, key dates. Making tax digital for Income Tax+1
  • Webinars and videos aimed at sole traders, landlords and agents – for example HMRC’s “Get ready for Making Tax Digital for Income Tax” video on YouTube. GOV.UK+1
    • [Watch here: Get ready for Making Tax Digital – Income Tax on YouTube] (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-nL4mpOh1_A)
  • Agent toolkits and promotional materials for accountants/bookkeepers so they can prepare and support clients. GOV.UK
  • Timeline-pages for key dates: “MTD for Income Tax – dates you need to know”. Making tax digital for Income Tax
  • Letters and notifications to affected taxpayers (based on prior returns) to let them know when they will be required. Mondaq+1

🎯 Who they’re targeting

  • Sole traders and landlords (unincorporated) with qualifying income above thresholds.
  • Accountants, agents, bookkeepers – so that they can help their clients get ready.
  • Eventually the broader population of self-employed and property income earners (as thresholds move lower).

📡 How they’re doing it

  • Digital adverts, promotion via GOV.UK pages, campaign microsite.
  • Webinars, recorded videos, newsletters.
  • Direct letters/emails to taxpayers identified as likely to be in-scope.
  • Toolkits for agents to use when talking to their clients.
  • Step-by-step guides published on GOV.UK.

🕒 When

  • The campaign launch is live now. According to one commentary, HMRC planned “three bigger bursts of paid-for marketing from Sept/Oct time” as of mid-2025.
  • The key legal start date: 6 April 2026 for first cohort. So the “preparation window” is between now and then.
  • Quarterly deadlines then fall in August/November/February/May for the first year of operation.

What else useful to know

  • Software choice matters: You’ll need software that is “MTD-compatible.” If you already use cloud accounting (e.g., Xero, QuickBooks, FreeAgent) you may already be well placed. If you’re using spreadsheets alone you’ll likely need bridging software or a move.
  • Digital link: If you use more than one piece of software (e.g., sales system + spreadsheet) you’ll need to ensure data flows digitally (not manual copy-paste) to meet the “digital links” requirement.
  • Split incomes: If you have both self-employment and property income, both count for threshold checks and you will send separate quarterly updates for each income stream under some regimes.
  • Business bank account or clean records: Particularly for landlords, mixing personal and business transactions can complicate the digital record-keeping requirements.
  • Prepare early = less stress: Even if you’re not yet mandated (because your income’s below the threshold now) getting systems in place ahead of time means you’ll be ready when the deadline hits.
  • Penalties: The old system of late-return penalties will morph into a “points-based” scheme (for some aspects) under MTD for ITSA.
  • Exemptions apply: If you are digitally excluded for legitimate reasons (age, disability, location, religion) you may apply for an exemption – so check if this applies to you. [please see our recent blog including more details here]

How Black & White Accounting Can Help You Every Step of the Way

At Black & White Accounting we’re geared up for this change – and we’re here to make it as seamless as possible for you. Here’s how we support:

  1. Readiness health-check – We’ll assess your income streams (self-employed, property) and check if you’re in-scope, when your start date is, and what your software & record-keeping looks like now.
  2. Software selection & implementation – Whether you need to upgrade, adopt a new solution, or migrate your practice, we’ll guide and manage that, ensuring the software is MTD-approved and fits your needs.
  3. Record-keeping process design – We’ll help you set up the digital workflows: bank feeds, receipt capture, linking property systems, separate streams for self-employment vs property, ensuring the digital links are valid.
  4. Quarterly updates handled – We’ll manage the quarterly update process (preparation, submission) so you don’t have to worry about deadlines slipping.
  5. Year-end transition support – We’ll integrate the quarterly updates into your final declaration, manage any other income elements, and ensure the end-of-year submission is correct.
  6. Ongoing training & support – If you or your team need help using the new software, understanding the changes, or making the most of the digital tools, we’ll provide training.
  7. Peace-of-mind compliance – With us in your corner, you’ll avoid the last-minute panic, reduce the risk of penalties and be in control of your tax position rather than it controlling you.

Final Word

The adverts, the campaign, the dates = they’re all real. You do not just “take our word for it” anymore: HMRC has signalled loud and clear that this change is coming, and you’ll want to be ahead of it, not scrambling behind it.
It’s just a shame that the message didn’t arrive sooner or more loudly for many. But the good news is: you still have time (though maybe not as much as you’d like).

If you’re a sole trader or landlord with income approaching the thresholds, now is the time. At Black & White Accounting we’d love to help you turn what could feel like a burden into a competitive advantage – better data, stronger control, smoother tax-affairs.

Feel free to drop us a note if you’d like a readiness check, or want to see how your current systems stack up against MTD’s requirements. We’re ready when you are.

posts.title: Salary v Dividend: The Corporation Tax Impact in 2025
posts.excerpt: Directors—Are You Still Paying Yourself the Smart Way? You’re a company director. You’ve got profits to extract. But every year, the same question rears its head: “Should I take a salary, a dividend, or a mix of both?” In 2025, the answer matters more than ever—because recent changes to Corporation Tax rates, dividend allowances, and […]
posts.content:
Directors—Are You Still Paying Yourself the Smart Way?

You’re a company director. You’ve got profits to extract. But every year, the same question rears its head:

“Should I take a salary, a dividend, or a mix of both?”

In 2025, the answer matters more than ever—because recent changes to Corporation Tax rates, dividend allowances, and National Insurance thresholds mean your old strategy may no longer be your best one.

At Black & White Accounting Limited, we help ambitious directors squeeze every drop of value from their company without stepping into a tax trap.

So let’s unpack the salary vs dividend decision in 2025—and help you take home more, the smart way.

🧾 The Basics: How Salary and Dividends Work

Salary is paid via PAYE, like any employee. It’s:

  • A deductible expense for your company (reduces profit and Corporation Tax)
  • Subject to Income Tax and National Insurance (NI)
  • Can help qualify for state pension and mortgage applications

Dividends are paid out of post-tax profits. They’re:

  • Not deductible for Corporation Tax
  • Taxed personally at lower rates than salary
  • Not subject to NI (that’s a win!)
  • Only payable if the company has distributable profits

Both have pros and cons. But 2025 has shaken up the numbers.

📈 2025 Tax Update Recap

Here’s what’s changed—and what’s hurting directors the most:

🚨 Corporation Tax Bands (since April 2023)

  • Up to £50,000 profit → 19%
  • Over £250,000 profit → 25%
  • Between = tapered marginal relief

👉 This makes salary more valuable as a deduction for companies over £50k profit.

🚨 Dividend Allowance Shrunk (Again)

  • 2022/23: £2,000
  • 2023/24: £1,000
  • 2024/25: £500

Yep—just £500 is now tax-free. Everything above that gets taxed at:

  • 8.75% (basic rate)
  • 33.75% (higher rate)
  • 39.35% (additional rate)

💥 This makes large dividend strategies less tax-friendly—especially for high earners.

🧮 The Numbers: 2025 Salary vs Dividend Comparison

Let’s say your company has £50,000 in profits to pay you, and you’re the sole shareholder.

Scenario A: All Dividends

  • Corporation Tax (19%) = £9,500
  • Remaining = £40,500
  • Dividend tax (basic rate) = ~£3,500
  • Take-home = ~£37,000

Scenario B: Salary up to £12,570 + Dividends

  • Salary is tax-free (within personal allowance)
  • Company saves ~£2,400 in Corporation Tax (on the salary deduction)
  • Dividends from remaining profits = ~£37,000
  • Dividend tax = lower because of reduced profit
  • Take-home = ~£38,500

💡 In 2025, blending salary + dividends is more tax-efficient than pure dividends for most director/shareholders.

✅ When to Lean Into Salary

You might want to increase salary if:

  • You’re near the Corporation Tax taper zone (£50k–£250k)
  • You want to build up qualifying income for state pension or borrowing
  • You have little to no other income (and can use personal allowance tax-free)
  • You want to make larger pension contributions—these are salary-linked

Bonus: Salary counts as earned income, which helps with:

  • Mortgage applications
  • Personal pension relief
  • Child benefit thresholds

✅ When Dividends Still Work

Dividends still shine if:

  • You want simplicity and flexibility
  • You’ve already hit your National Insurance thresholds
  • You want to avoid employer NI contributions (currently 13.8%)
  • You have multiple shareholders (can vary dividends easily)

Just keep an eye on:

  • Available post-tax profits
  • Dividend documentation (minutes + vouchers)
  • PAYE vs dividend balance, especially if you receive other income

⚠️ The Danger Zone: Taking Too Much as Dividends

We’ve seen directors get caught out by:

  • Taking dividends when there’s no profit (illegal, and red-flagged by HMRC)
  • Using dividends to repay overdrawn directors’ loans without paperwork
  • Assuming dividends are always cheaper—they’re not, post-2025 changes

📉 A poor drawdown strategy = personal tax shock + Section 455 charge + missed opportunities.

🤖 What About MTD Software?

Using software like Xero, QuickBooks, Sage or FreeAgent lets us:

  • Track real-time profits (so you know what’s available for dividends)
  • Run simulations of different extraction strategies
  • Create payslips and dividend vouchers instantly
  • Make quarterly planning part of your routine—not just a year-end panic

🤝 How Black & White Accounting Helps You Win

We don’t just file tax returns—we plan your director wealth strategy.

You get:

  • 📊 A personalised salary/dividend split plan
  • 🧮 Real-time profit tracking via cloud software
  • 💬 Ongoing advice when profits rise (or drop)
  • 🧾 Proper documentation to stay HMRC-safe
  • 💡 Year-end reviews to optimise extraction before deadlines hit

And yes—we help you adjust your strategy every year as tax laws change.

🚀 Final Word: Don’t Let Outdated Advice Cost You in 2025

The dividend-only model worked in 2018.
In 2025? It could be costing you thousands.

Whether you’re just starting out or scaling fast, the right extraction strategy protects your profits, your cash flow, and your future.

Let’s get it working for you.

posts.title: Capital Gains Tax When Selling a Property – Everything You Need to Know
posts.excerpt: Selling a property can be exciting, but when you’re not living in it, the tax implications can quickly take the shine off your profit. Enter Capital Gains Tax (CGT): a crucial part of property ownership that every landlord, investor, and second-home owner needs to understand. Whether you’re an estate or letting agent helping clients navigate […]
posts.content:
Selling a property can be exciting, but when you’re not living in it, the tax implications can quickly take the shine off your profit. Enter Capital Gains Tax (CGT): a crucial part of property ownership that every landlord, investor, and second-home owner needs to understand.

Whether you’re an estate or letting agent helping clients navigate a sale, or a landlord planning ahead, here’s everything you need to know, and how Black & White Accounting can help you manage it smoothly, efficiently, and without any nasty surprises.

💰 What Is Capital Gains Tax (CGT)?

Capital Gains Tax is a tax you pay on the profit (the “gain”) when you sell or dispose of an asset that’s increased in value, including property that isn’t your main home.

You don’t pay CGT on the full sale price, only on the gain, the difference between what you paid for the property and what you sell it for, after deducting allowable costs like stamp duty, legal fees, and estate agent commissions.

For example:
If you bought a flat for £200,000, spent £5,000 on buying costs and £10,000 improving it, and later sold it for £300,000, your taxable gain would be £85,000 (£300,000 – £200,000 – £5,000 – £10,000).

🧮 How to Calculate the Capital Gain

Calculating your gain isn’t just about the headline figures, it’s about getting the details right. Here’s how to do it:

  1. Sale price (or market value if given away)
  2. Minus the purchase price
  3. Minus allowable costs (such as legal fees, stamp duty, estate agent fees, and capital improvements, but not repairs or maintenance)
  4. Minus your annual CGT allowance

For the 2025/26 tax year, the annual CGT exemption is £3,000 per individual, meaning you only pay tax on gains above that amount.

📈 Current CGT Rates on Property

CGT rates depend on your overall income:

  • 18% for basic rate taxpayers (on the portion of the gain within the basic rate band)
  • 24% for higher and additional rate taxpayers (since the reduction from 28% announced in 2024)

These rates apply specifically to residential property gains. For other assets, the rates may differ.

If you jointly own a property, each owner calculates their gain and applies their own CGT allowance and tax rate.

📈 Current CGT Rates on Property

CGT rates depend on your overall income:

  • 18% for basic rate taxpayers (on the portion of the gain within the basic rate band)
  • 24% for higher and additional rate taxpayers (since the reduction from 28% announced in 2024)

These rates apply specifically to residential property gains for individuals. For other assets, the rates may differ.

If you jointly own a property, each owner calculates their gain and applies their own CGT allowance and tax rate.

💼 If the property is owned through a limited company, the rules are different, companies don’t pay Capital Gains Tax. Instead, they pay Corporation Tax on the gain, currently at 25% (or the applicable small profits rate if the company qualifies). This can sometimes make company ownership more tax-efficient, but it depends on your broader financial situation and how profits are extracted from the business.

🏠 Reliefs That Can Reduce or Eliminate CGT

There are several reliefs that can reduce how much CGT you owe:

  • Private Residence Relief (PRR): If the property was your main home at any point, part of the gain may be exempt.
  • Lettings Relief: May apply in limited cases if you once lived in the property and later let it out.
  • Spousal Transfers: Assets can be transferred between spouses or civil partners tax-free, which can help use both annual exemptions.

The rules can get complex, especially for landlords who’ve lived in the property, made improvements, or own jointly. That’s where professional advice makes all the difference.

⏱️ The 60-Day Reporting Rule (and How We Got Here)

Since April 2020, UK residents who sell a residential property that triggers CGT have been required to report and pay the tax to HMRC within a short window.

Initially, this was just 30 days, a deadline that caught many people out. But after widespread feedback from taxpayers and professionals, HMRC extended the window to 60 days in October 2021.

This means that within 60 days of completion, you must:

  1. Report the sale via HMRC’s online “UK Property Return” service, and
  2. Pay any CGT due based on your best estimate at the time.

You’ll still need to include the gain in your annual Self Assessment, but this separate 60-day return is mandatory, and penalties apply for late filing or payment.

⚙️ Why This Rule Exists

The 60-day rule was introduced to speed up CGT collection and reduce underpayment risk. Previously, CGT on property sales could be declared more than a year after completion, now, HMRC gets the tax in real time.

The aim is to improve compliance and make sure everyone pays the right tax at the right time, though it does add an extra administrative step for property owners and agents to manage.

🧭 How Black & White Accounting Can Help

At Black & White Accounting, we make sure your clients, and you, never have to stress about CGT deadlines or complex calculations. Here’s how we help:

✅ Accurate CGT calculations – We identify all allowable costs, reliefs, and exemptions to ensure you never pay more than you should.
✅ 60-day return filing – We prepare and submit the HMRC report promptly, avoiding fines and interest.
✅ Strategic planning – We help landlords and investors plan ahead to minimise future tax bills.
✅ Seamless support for agents – We work with estate and letting agents to assist clients from the moment a sale is agreed, ensuring a smooth, compliant process.
✅ Clear communication – No jargon, no surprises, just black & white advice that makes sense.

🚀 Ready to Sell? Let’s Make It Simple.

Whether your client is selling their first buy-to-let or a large portfolio, Capital Gains Tax doesn’t have to be complicated. With the right help, it’s just another box ticked on the road to a successful sale.

At Black & White Accounting, we make property tax compliance simple, smart, and stress-free, for landlords, investors, and the agents who support them.

📩 Get in touch today to find out how we can help your clients manage Capital Gains Tax with confidence and clarity.

posts.title: How to Structure Property Ownership Tax Efficiently
posts.excerpt: Property investment can be a brilliant way to build long-term wealth, but how you structure your ownership can make a huge difference to the amount of tax you pay, both now and in the future. With different options available, from holding properties in your own name to forming partnerships or companies, the right choice can […]
posts.content:
Property investment can be a brilliant way to build long-term wealth, but how you structure your ownership can make a huge difference to the amount of tax you pay, both now and in the future. With different options available, from holding properties in your own name to forming partnerships or companies, the right choice can shape your cash flow, tax position, and growth potential.

At Black & White Accounting, we help landlords and investors find the most tax-efficient structure for their portfolios and plan for the future with confidence.

💡 The Main Structures for Property Ownership

There’s no one-size-fits-all answer, but understanding the key options is the first step to making an informed decision. Let’s break them down.

👤 1. Sole Trader (Individual Ownership)

This is the most common and straightforward structure, especially for first-time landlords. You personally own the property, receive the income, and pay tax on your profits through Self Assessment.

Pros:

  • Simple to set up and manage.
  • No separate company accounts or filings.
  • Access to personal tax allowances and reliefs.

Cons:

  • Income is taxed at your personal rate, which could be up to 45%.
  • Limited ability to deduct mortgage interest for residential lets.
  • No protection if something goes wrong, as you and the property are legally the same entity.

Best suited for: smaller landlords with modest rental income or those testing the waters of property investment.

👥 2. Partnership

A partnership allows two or more people to own property together, sharing income, expenses, and responsibilities. Each partner is taxed individually on their share of the profits.

Pros:

  • Flexible profit-sharing arrangements.
  • Easy to add or remove partners.
  • Some flexibility in transferring interests between partners.

Cons:

  • Partners are personally liable for debts and taxes.
  • Still subject to the same mortgage interest restrictions as sole traders.
  • Can become complex if one partner wants to exit.

Best suited for: families or business partners managing multiple properties together with shared goals.

🏢 3. Limited Company

Owning property through a limited company has become increasingly popular, especially for higher-rate taxpayers and those building larger portfolios.

Pros:

  • Profits are taxed at the Corporation Tax rate of 25%, not personal income tax rates.
  • Full mortgage interest can usually be deducted as an expense.
  • Greater control over reinvestment and long-term planning.
  • Limited liability protection for directors and shareholders.

Cons:

  • More administrative work and annual filing requirements.
  • Mortgage options can be more limited and sometimes more expensive.
  • If you take profits out personally, further tax may apply through dividends.

Best suited for: investors building a property business or planning long-term growth.

⚖️ 4. Limited Liability Partnership (LLP)

An LLP blends elements of a traditional partnership with some of the legal protections of a company.

Pros:

  • Partners’ liability is limited to what they invest.
  • Offers flexibility in profit allocation.
  • Can help with succession planning or complex ownership structures.

Cons:

  • Still taxed personally on profits, not at Corporation Tax rates.
  • More administrative work than a standard partnership.
  • Not always suitable for smaller portfolios.

Best suited for: professional investors or family groups managing significant property assets who value flexibility and legal protection.

🔄 Converting Your Portfolio into a Limited Company

Many landlords who started as individuals or partnerships are now choosing to incorporate their property business to benefit from lower Corporation Tax rates and full interest deductions.

It is possible to transfer your portfolio into a company, but it must be done carefully to avoid unexpected tax charges. HMRC may view the transfer as a sale, potentially triggering Capital Gains Tax (CGT) and Stamp Duty Land Tax (SDLT).

However, reliefs can sometimes apply, such as:

  • Incorporation Relief for CGT, if you run a genuine property business with multiple properties and active management.
  • SDLT Partnership Relief, if structured correctly.

At Black & White Accounting, we assess your individual circumstances, model the financial impact, and manage the process end-to-end to ensure it’s done efficiently and compliantly.

💼 Other Useful Considerations

When deciding how to structure property ownership, it’s important to consider:

  • Long-term goals – short-term tax savings might not always align with future plans.
  • Exit strategy – how you plan to sell, pass on, or refinance your properties.
  • Financing – lenders often have different criteria for companies versus individuals.
  • Inheritance planning – some structures make it easier to transfer wealth efficiently.

Good tax planning doesn’t just reduce your bill; it also gives you more flexibility, security, and control.

🧭 How Black & White Accounting Can Help

At Black & White Accounting, we specialise in helping landlords and property investors structure, grow, and manage their portfolios tax efficiently. Our services include:

✅ Strategic advice on the most tax-efficient ownership structure.
✅ Incorporation planning and execution.
✅ Ongoing accounting, bookkeeping, and compliance support.
✅ CGT and SDLT relief planning.
✅ Collaboration with estate and letting agents to support landlords from acquisition to sale.

Our goal is to make sure landlords, and the agents who support them, understand every option and make informed, profitable decisions.

🚀 Plan Smart, Save Tax, Grow Your Portfolio

The way you own property can have a lasting impact on your returns. Whether you’re starting out, expanding, or restructuring, the right advice now can save thousands in the long run.

At Black & White Accounting, we turn complex property tax planning into clear, actionable strategies, helping you and your clients achieve the best outcomes.

📩 Get in touch today to find out how we can help you structure your property investments tax efficiently.

posts.title: What exemptions from Making Tax Digital for Income Tax (MTD IT) the HM Revenue & Customs will accept
posts.excerpt: At Black & White Accounting, we pride ourselves on staying ahead of the curve so that you don’t have to. With the announcement from HMRC that applications are now open for exemptions on the grounds of digital exclusion, now is the time for sole traders and landlords to act, seek clarity, and if necessary, secure […]
posts.content:
At Black & White Accounting, we pride ourselves on staying ahead of the curve so that you don’t have to. With the announcement from HMRC that applications are now open for exemptions on the grounds of digital exclusion, now is the time for sole traders and landlords to act, seek clarity, and if necessary, secure their exemption from MTD IT. Here’s a full breakdown of what you need to know.

📣 Big news: Exemption applications now open

HMRC has recently confirmed that individuals who believe they’re digitally excluded can now apply for an exemption from MTD for Income Tax. In summary:

  • From 6 April 2026, individuals with qualifying income (self-employment or property) over £50,000 will have to use MTD for Income Tax.
  • From 6 April 2027, the threshold drops to £30,000.
  • From 6 April 2028, it will be £20,000 (for the 2026-27 year) as law is extended.
  • But if you can demonstrate digital exclusion, you may be exempt from using the MTD digital system.

So, if you’re reading this and thinking: “Am I going to have to switch to digital reporting next year?”; the answer is likely yes, unless an exemption applies to you. And that’s where we step in.

✅ What kinds of scenarios will HMRC accept for exemption

HMRC defines “digitally excluded” as cases where “it’s not reasonably practicable” to use compatible software and keep digital records. Examples cited include:

  • A taxpayer’s age, health condition or disability means they cannot use a computer/tablet/smartphone/software.
  • The taxpayer lives in a location where internet access is unavailable or unsuitable, and no suitable alternative location is reasonably accessible.
  • A practising member of a religious society or order whose beliefs are incompatible with using electronic communications or keeping electronic records.

Importantly: HMRC says that the taxpayer must show how their personal circumstances make digital compliance not reasonably practicable, not just inconvenient.

🚫 What situations HMRC will not accept

Being clear about these will help you decide whether an exemption application is credible, and how we at Black & White Accounting can help you build that case:

HMRC guidance states that the following alone will not qualify for exemption:

  • Simply because you have always filed a paper tax return in the past.
  • You are unfamiliar with accountancy software – because unfamiliarity alone does not make digital reporting “not reasonably practicable”.
  • You only have a small number of digital records to create each year.
  • It will cost extra time or extra money for you to sign up for and use MTD-software (unless that cost is combined with other factors like disability, remoteness, etc).

In short: HMRC expects you to make a strong case. If you simply dislike or find digital systems inconvenient, you won’t likely qualify.

🧾 How to apply to be exempt – and how we help you

Here is the application process, step by step – and where Black & White Accounting can take the lead to support you all the way.

Step 1: Check whether you need to use MTD for Income Tax

  • Work out if you’re within the thresholds (over £50,000 from April 2026, £30,000 from April 2027, £20,000 from April 2028) for self-employment/property income.
  • If you’re below the threshold, you aren’t yet mandated,  but you may opt in early.
  • If you are above, then prepare to join MTD unless you secure a valid exemption.

How Black & White helps: We’ll review your income streams and projections, confirm your threshold status, and advise whether you’re in scope and therefore likely to need either to comply or to consider an exemption.

Step 2: Decide if you have genuine grounds for “digital exclusion”

  • Review whether any of your personal circumstances match HMRC’s examples: health/disability, poor internet access or geographical remoteness, religious beliefs.
  • Gather evidence: perhaps a statement of access issues, medical reports, religious society membership, or combinations thereof.

How we help: We’ll assist you in assessing your circumstances against HMRC’s criteria, pull together supporting documentation, and formulate the narrative why MTD is not reasonably practicable for you.

Step 3: Submit the application to HMRC

  • The application must be made before you are required to use MTD. HMRC aims to respond within 28 days.
  • Application can be made by phone or writing to HMRC (Self Assessment general enquiries). The letter should be headed: “Making Tax Digital for Income Tax – digitally excluded application”.
  • You’ll need to provide: your National Insurance number, name, address; how you currently submit your tax return; whether you use an agent (and what they do); your reasons and supporting information; details of any additional needs.

How we help: We will draft or review the letter/application, ensure all details are accurate, liaise with HMRC (if authorised) and monitor the process so you don’t miss deadlines or required follow-up.

Step 4: After applying – what happens next?

  • HMRC will issue a decision letter. If approved, you may continue submitting Self Assessment returns (paper or non-MTD digital) instead of joining the quarterly MTD updates.
  • If HMRC rejects, you have 30 days from the date on the letter to appeal.
  • Even while you wait for HMRC’s response, you should still prepare as though you may have to join MTD, keeping your records up to date and software ready.
  • If your circumstances change (for instance, your disability improves or internet access becomes available) you must notify HMRC, because your exemption may no longer apply.

How we help: We’ll keep you on track with deadlines, manage your record-keeping whether you’re joining MTD or awaiting an exemption decision, and assist with the appeal if required.

🌟 Why choose Black & White Accounting as your partner

  • We’re a fast-growing firm with a dynamic approach: we bring the latest regulatory updates (such as this MTD IT exemption) to our clients proactively.
  • We specialise in helping small business owners, sole traders and landlords – the very groups most impacted by MTD IT.
  • We take the hassle off your plate: from eligibility assessments and income-threshold reviews, to compiling supporting evidence, drafting the exemption application, liaising with HMRC, and preparing you for either scenario (compliance or exemption).
  • Whether you apply for exemption or move into full MTD-compliance, we provide ongoing support so you’re never left navigating unfamiliar software or new processes alone.
  • We believe in clarity, responsiveness and practical advice: no frightening jargon, just a clear path forward.

🔍 Final thoughts

The rollout of MTD for Income Tax is one of the biggest shifts in UK tax-admin for sole traders and landlords in many years. Being prepared matters. While the introduction of digital-recording and quarterly updates is the norm for most, the availability of exemption on grounds of digital exclusion gives a crucial lifeline for those whose circumstances genuinely make the digital route impractical.

If you think you might qualify for the exemption, or even if you’re unsure and want reassurance, now is the time to act.

At Black & White Accounting, we’re ready to help you every step of the way: from checking whether you’re in scope, reviewing your circumstances for digital exclusion, to applying for exemption or guiding you seamlessly into MTD-compliance.

👉 Get in touch with us today, and let’s make sure your tax-journey is as smooth and stress-free as possible.

Let’s turn the unknown into “done and dusted”.

posts.title: Top Tax Tips for Landlords – Make Your Property Profits Work Smarter
posts.excerpt: Being a landlord can be incredibly rewarding, but it also comes with a maze of tax rules that can trip up even the most experienced investors. From allowable expenses and recordkeeping to choosing the right ownership structure, smart tax planning can make the difference between a good return and a great one. At Black & […]
posts.content:
Being a landlord can be incredibly rewarding, but it also comes with a maze of tax rules that can trip up even the most experienced investors. From allowable expenses and recordkeeping to choosing the right ownership structure, smart tax planning can make the difference between a good return and a great one.

At Black & White Accounting, we work with landlords, property investors, and agents every day to make sure they’re not paying a penny more in tax than they should, while keeping their property business fully compliant and future-ready.

Here are our top tax tips for landlords to help you keep more of what you earn.

💡 1. Claim Every Allowable Expense

The golden rule: if an expense is wholly and exclusively for the purpose of renting out your property, it’s probably deductible.

Typical allowable expenses include:

  • Letting agent fees and management costs
  • Accountancy and legal fees related to rental activity
  • Property repairs and maintenance (but not improvements)
  • Buildings and contents insurance
  • Utilities, council tax, and ground rent (if paid by you)
  • Cleaning, gardening, and general upkeep
  • Travel costs for property management or inspections

Not allowable:

  • Improvements that increase the property’s value (these may count toward Capital Gains Tax relief later)
  • Your own time or labour
  • Personal costs or anything not directly linked to the rental

Tip: Keep detailed records and receipts; small costs add up fast, and missing them means missing out on savings.

🏗️ 2. Get the Ownership Structure Right

How you own your properties can significantly affect how much tax you pay. Whether you’re starting out or expanding your portfolio, choosing the right structure is essential.

Sole Trader (Individual Ownership)
Simple to manage and ideal for smaller landlords, but profits are taxed at your personal income tax rate, and mortgage interest relief is restricted.

Partnership
Flexible profit sharing, useful for families or couples, but still taxed personally on each partner’s share.

Limited Company
Profits are taxed at the Corporation Tax rate of 25%, and full mortgage interest relief is available. However, extracting profits through dividends can add further tax.

Limited Liability Partnership (LLP)
A hybrid option offering partnership flexibility with some legal protection, best for more complex or professional setups.

More on this can be found in our blog here [week 3 blog link].

Tip: The right structure depends on your income, future goals, and portfolio size. Getting this wrong can be costly, but the right advice can unlock big long-term savings.

🧾 3. Keep Great Records – It Pays Off

Good recordkeeping isn’t just about compliance, it’s about control. Clear, up-to-date records make it easier to:

  • Track profits and losses accurately
  • Claim every deduction you’re entitled to
  • Prepare for future tax changes (like MTD)
  • Make strategic decisions based on real-time data

Paper receipts and spreadsheets are becoming a thing of the past. Using a cloud-based accounting platform such as Xero, QuickBooks, or FreeAgent keeps everything organised and accessible, and it will soon be a requirement.

💻 4. Get Ready for Making Tax Digital (MTD)

The next phase of Making Tax Digital (MTD) is coming in April 2026, and it will affect landlords with property income over £50,000 (and those earning over £30,000 by 2027).

Instead of one annual Self Assessment, landlords will need to:

  • Keep digital records of all income and expenses
  • Submit quarterly updates to HMRC via approved software
  • File a final annual declaration

Getting set up early means you’ll avoid stress later, and you’ll gain better insight into your property finances throughout the year.

More on this can be found in our blog here [https://blackandwhiteaccounting.co.uk/mtd-for-landlords-2026-and-beyond-everything-you-need-to-know/].

💷 5. Don’t Forget About Capital Allowances and Reliefs

If you let out furnished holiday properties, you may be able to claim Capital Allowances on items such as furniture, fixtures, and fittings.

Other valuable reliefs include:

  • Private Residence Relief (PRR) if you’ve lived in the property at any point
  • Lettings Relief (limited cases)
  • Replacement of Domestic Items Relief for replacing furniture and appliances in residential lets

Tip: Knowing which reliefs apply, and when, can shave thousands off your tax bill.

📆 6. Plan Ahead to Minimise Your Tax Burden

Strategic planning is key. Consider:

  • Timing property sales to make use of your annual CGT allowance (£3,000 per person in 2025/26)
  • Splitting ownership with a spouse or civil partner to use both allowances
  • Reinvesting profits to reduce immediate tax liabilities
  • Reviewing mortgage arrangements under different ownership structures

The earlier you plan, the more flexibility you’ll have to reduce your tax exposure.

⚙️ How Black & White Accounting Can Help

At Black & White Accounting, we specialise in helping landlords and property investors stay compliant, tax-efficient, and stress-free. Here’s how we support you and your clients:

✅ Expert advice on ownership structures and incorporation
✅ Full bookkeeping and accounting support
✅ MTD-ready software setup and training
✅ Maximising allowable expenses and reliefs
✅ 60-day CGT reporting and planning for sales
✅ Ongoing strategic tax planning for future growth

We also partner with estate and letting agents to help their clients make smarter financial decisions, strengthening relationships and adding value to your services.

🚀 Smarter Planning, Bigger Savings

With the right structure, the right records, and the right advice, landlords can keep more of their hard-earned profits.

At Black & White Accounting, we make property tax simple, transparent, and efficient, so landlords and agents can focus on what they do best: growing their portfolios and achieving long-term success.

posts.title: What “Could Be” in the 2025 Budget for Landlords and Property Owners – and How to Prepare?

posts.content:
The calendar is ticking towards the Autumn Budget 2025, and for landlords and property investors, it feels like the calm before a storm. While nothing is confirmed yet, several credible rumours are circulating that could significantly impact rental income, property portfolios, and tax liabilities. This is your chance, both as an estate/letting agent and for your landlord clients, to get ahead, plan smart, and ensure you’re not caught off-guard.

At Black & White Accounting we’re already working with agents and landlords to assess potential scenarios, model their impact, and prepare strategies. Let’s walk through what might be coming – note that what follows are only possible changes, not guarantees – and talk about how to prepare.

🔍 Key Rumoured Changes for Landlords & Property Owners

Here are some of the most frequently discussed possibilities ahead of the 2025 Budget:

  • An 8% National Insurance‐style levy on rental income: There’s speculation that the Treasury is considering applying National Insurance (NI) contributions to rental income for the first time (currently rental income is not subject to NI).
  • Replacement or overhaul of Stamp Duty Land Tax (SDLT): One idea floated is an annual property tax or a restructured form of SDLT, possibly spreading payments or changing rates for investment properties.
  • Further changes to Capital Gains Tax (CGT) on property disposals: Speculation includes cuts to allowances, higher rates, or extending CGT to main homes in certain scenarios.
  • Freezing or adjusting income tax thresholds and reliefs: Though not specific only to landlords, freezing thresholds means higher tax burdens even without rate increases.
  • Higher taxation or levies on high-value property portfolios or second homes: Reports suggest that properties above certain values may face extra charges or be targeted for new taxes.

📌 Why Agents and Landlords Should Care

  • Planning ahead is a differentiator: As an estate or letting agent, you add value to your service when you help clients anticipate tax change risk rather than react to it.
  • Portfolio decisions may need to be accelerated: If changes like CGT cuts or new levies are confirmed, clients might decide to buy, sell, or restructure now rather than later.
  • Structure and ownership matter: Different ownership structures (personal ownership, limited company, partnerships) will bear tax changes differently. Knowing how potential changes affect each structure is key.
  • Cash-flow and compliance will be pressured: With new taxes or levies, landlords may face higher costs, stricter reporting, or debugging of outdated structures.

🔧 How to Prepare – Practical Steps

Here are some actions agents can encourage their landlord clients to take now, so they’re not scrambling when the Budget hits:

  1. Review current portfolio structure
    • Look at how properties are held (sole name, partnership, company) and what tax implications each has under potential changes.
    • Model what an NI levy on rental income or CGT cut would do in your client’s case.
  2. Update ownership and financing strategy
    • If clients are considering switching to a limited company structure, it may be worth starting discussions now.
    • Check mortgage terms, lender covenants and tax cost of transfer.
  3. Maintain impeccable records and cash-flow forecasts
    • Good record-keeping makes it easier to spot how new rules might impact returns.
    • Consider stress-testing portfolios with higher tax burdens or new levy scenarios.
  4. Tax & portfolio review meeting
    • Schedule a strategic review with an accountant or tax adviser to consider options before the Budget is announced.
    • Watch for rumours and announcements – being ready means being able to act quickly.
  5. Focus on timing
    • If you suspect a CGT allowance cut or new levy, timing of sales, ownership changes or acquisitions could matter.
    • Plan for different tax environments and ensure you’re ready for change.

🤝 How Black & White Accounting Can Help You & Your Clients

At Black & White Accounting we specialise in property tax and investment structuring. Here’s how we partner with estate and letting agents and their clients to navigate this uncertain terrain:

  • Pre-Budget scenario modelling: We run different tax change scenarios (NI levy, CGT changes, SDLT reform) so landlords can see the potential impact on their business.
  • Ownership structure review: We advise whether personal, partnership or limited company ownership continues to make sense under possible new rules.
  • Tax planning & compliance support: We ensure clients are set up with the right reporting systems, anticipate changes, and avoid last minute surprises.
  • Supporting agents and their landlord clients: We provide white-label materials, webinars or guidance you can share with your clients to add value to your service.
  • Ongoing monitoring and agility: Once the Budget is announced, we help clients respond quickly – whether that means restructuring, re-financing, sale planning or adjusting strategy.

🚀 Final Thoughts – Act Now, Don’t Wait

The key message? Don’t wait for the Budget to land before doing something. Rumours may yet change, but the early signals suggest significant tax pressure for landlords and property owners. By preparing now – reviewing structure, modelling outcomes, getting records in order – you position yourself and your clients to act, not react.

As an estate or letting agent, partnering with Black & White Accounting means you are offering your clients more than just a property service – you’re supporting their financial strategy, growth and resilience.

📩 Get in touch with us today and let’s build a pre-Budget readiness plan for you and your landlord clients – so you’re ready whatever the Chancellor announces.
